sense.def: the amount of money a person regularly receives for a job, usually when paid for the number of hours worked
dictionaryExamples: The factory pays low/high/fair/decent wages.
The average wage is $8.50 an hour.
the minimum wage
a laborer's hourly/daily/weekly wage
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I know it is not nice for my family but I [earn] a good wage for that. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: the part of the body above and slightly narrower than the hips
dictionaryExamples: a small/narrow/tiny/large waist
These pants are a little tight around my waist.
She has a 26-inch waist.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Chris was holding his arm tight[ly] around Claire's waist. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: to stay in a place until someone or something arrives, or until someone or something is ready for you
dictionaryExamples: I waited for her in the corridor while she went in to see the doctor.
There were a lot of people waiting to use the telephone.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I don't like [the] college break time[s], because I must wait 15 minutes. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; French

sense.def: used to say how excited you are about something that you are going to do
dictionaryExamples: I can't wait to see him.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I can't wait to see you! Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: to be late so that someone has to wait for you
dictionaryExamples: I'm sorry to have kept you waiting.
The dentist kept me waiting for a long time.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm sorry for keep[ing] you waiting. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: said in order to interrupt someone, or to get their attention or when you have suddenly thought of something important
dictionaryExamples: Now, wait a minute - I don't agree with that.
Wait  - I just had an idea.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Oh! Wait a minute... First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: to wait to discover what will happen
dictionaryExamples: We'll wait and see what she says.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We will just have to wait and see.  . . . . Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: to not do something until something else happens
dictionaryExamples: We'll wait till Jane gets here before we start eating.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The wedding will be at midday, but bec[a]use Spanish [people] are the most unpunctual people in the world, maybe we'll have to wait until half past twelve to start the ceremony. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: when you stay in one place until someone or something arrives, or someone or something is ready for you
dictionaryExamples: a long wait
well worth the wait
We had a three-hour wait before we could see the doctor.
The long wait for the doctor/to see the doctor really made me anxious.

sense.def: a man who works in a restaurant, bringing food to customers
dictionaryExamples: The waiter brought our drinks.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The waiter and waitress working there are kind and friendly. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: a woman who works in a restaurant, bringing food to customers
dictionaryExamples: She's working as a waitress right now.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She is a waitress [and] she likes this job. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: to move forward by putting one foot in front of the other and then repeating the action
dictionaryExamples: I walked home.
A cat was walking along the top of the fence.
He walks a mile to work every morning.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like to walk by [the] River Exe. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Slovak

sense.def: to walk with someone in order to guide them or keep them safe
dictionaryExamples: He walked me to my house.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Then we went to the bar beside the restaurant to have a last drink and he walked me home. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: to walk with a dog to give the dog exercise
dictionaryExamples: I walk the dog twice a day.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Well, I suppose in my opinion you should walk the dog three times a day. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: a trip that you make by walking, often for enjoyment
dictionaryExamples: He had/went for/took a walk to get some air.
Every afternoon she takes her dog out for a walk.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After dinner we watch television, [and] sometimes we go for a walk. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Polish

sense.def: a trip that takes a short time/ten minutes, etc., when you walk
dictionaryExamples: The post office is just a five-minute walk from the house.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A fi[f]teen-minute walk was necessary to reach it and there were no neighbors around. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: a path or route where people can walk for enjoyment
dictionaryExamples: There are some lovely walks in the park.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The walk ends in Valli del Natisone, but from here there are 2 other different routes that can be chosen. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Italian

sense.def: someone who walks
dictionaryExamples: She is a very fast walker.
Children who take the bus home will leave in 5 minutes, but the walkers can leave now.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The next step is directly on the road. Here you have to learn to watch what different drivers, walkers, children, dogs, cats ... are doing and, the most important thing, to predict what they will do in the next seconds. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Italian

sense.def: the activity of going for a walk
dictionaryExamples: Walking is good exercise.
a pair of walking shoes
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In conclusion, I think walking is an ideal way of exercise as it combines healthy body and spirit. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: a vertical structure, often made of stone or brick, that divides or surrounds something
dictionaryExamples: The walls in this apartment are so thin you can hear just about every word the neighbors say.
The walls look kind of bare - can't we put some pictures up?
We had to climb over a ten-foot wall to get into the garden.
The Berlin Wall came down in 1989.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We will paint the wall orange. Key English Test; A2; Tamil

sense.def: a small folding case for carrying paper money and credit cards, used especially by men
dictionaryExamples: Have you seen my wallet anywhere?
He pulled out a big fat wallet stuffed with bills.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think I have left my wallet in your house. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: to walk around slowly in a relaxed way or without any clear purpose or direction
dictionaryExamples: We spent the morning wandering around the market.
He was here a minute ago, but he's wandered off somewhere.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you can't afford it you can just wander around the city and enjoy meeting people. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: If someone's attention/mind, etc., wanders, they start thinking about one subject when they should be thinking about a different subject.
dictionaryExamples: I was bored and my thoughts started to wander.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: His mind kept wandering off and he always found himself dreaming of her beautiful blue eyes, her long, dark eye-lashes and her soft, curled hair. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: to hope to have or do something, or to wish for something
dictionaryExamples: I want some chocolate.
She wants a word with you.
What do you want to eat?
Do you want me to take you to the station?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I just wanted to write a letter [to] you. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Farsi

sense.def: armed fighting between two or more countries or groups, or a particular example of this
dictionaryExamples: nuclear war
civil war
a war film/grave/hero
If this country goes to war we will have to face the fact that many people will die.
Britain and France declared war on Germany in 1939.
War broke out between the two countries after a border dispute.
They've been at war for the last five years.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was built by [the] British during the war. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: an attempt to stop something bad or illegal
dictionaryExamples: the war against crime/drugs
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Some years ago, she had given an interview [o]n a local channel, explaining why she chose to devote herself to the war against the destruction of the environment. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: a room or area in a hospital, where people receiving treatment stay
dictionaryExamples: She's in a ward on the fourth floor.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I spent two days alone in a ward [in] Biarritz's hospital. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: the set of clothes that you own, or a set of clothes worn at a particular time or for a particular situation
dictionaryExamples: I'll need a new wardrobe for my new job!
a stylish/casual/winter wardrobe
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Of course, jeans are always in a young person's wardrobe as they are always in fashion and now baggy trousers are becoming more and more popular. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: a large building for storing goods that are going to be sold
dictionaryExamples: We have several thousand of the books in our warehouse.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But new businesses are flourishing in the old warehouses by the river. Manufacturing and engineering firms have sprung in recent years and are keeping unemployement at record low. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: having a temperature between cool and hot
dictionaryExamples: Are you warm enough or should I turn up the heat?
She had her hands in her pockets to keep them warm.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like to [go] surfing there because [the] water is warm. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Hungarian

sense.def: describes clothes and covers made of a material that keeps you warm
dictionaryExamples: I don't have a warm winter coat.
Those gloves look nice and warm.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Remember you should wear warm clothes. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: friendly and loving
dictionaryExamples: They're a very warm family.
He has a nice, warm smile.
I'd like to give a warm welcome to our guests this evening.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He is warm and friendly. Preliminary English Test; B1; Arabic

sense.def: to become warm or make something become warm
dictionaryExamples: When the weather warms up, we'll go camping.
Rub the oil between your hands to warm it.
It takes a little while to warm up the house.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After they save[d] me, I put those gloves on to warm my hands. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: in a way that keeps you warm
dictionaryExamples: You're not dressed warmly enough - put a sweater on.

sense.def: in a friendly or loving way
dictionaryExamples: He shook my hand warmly.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He embraced me warmly and whispered 'You wouldn't have believed me.' First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: the heat that is produced by something
dictionaryExamples: the warmth of the sun
I have a T-shirt on under my sweater for extra warmth.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We lay down on the sand enjoying the warmth of the sun and listening to the birds. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: a friendly and loving quality in someone or something
dictionaryExamples: I still remember the warmth of their welcome.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They gave us so much when we were children, their love and their warmth, and now it is up to us to stay with them and give back the love we [recei]ved. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: to make someone realize a possible danger or problem, especially one in the future
dictionaryExamples: We were warned not to eat the fish.
Have you warned them (that) there will be an extra person for dinner?
I was warned against/off going to the east coast because it was so full of tourists.
This particular curry is extremely hot - be warned!
Put that ball down and come over here, Laura - I'm warning you!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I tried to warn him that there would be a lot of people looking at him. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: something that tells or shows you that something bad may happen
dictionaryExamples: There's a health  warning on every pack of cigarettes.
A bad storm can strike without warning.
Just a word of warning - restaurants in this area can be very expensive.
The Food and Drug Administration issued a warning to doctors about the dangers of the drug.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Without any warning he pushed [me]. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: a person who has experience and skill in fighting in a war, especially in the past
dictionaryExamples: These warriors used spears made from iron.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is true that the Vikings were warriors, some would say bloodthirsty as well, but that is something I will leave to you to judge. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: If you are wary of someone or something, you do not trust them completely.
dictionaryExamples: She's still wary of strangers.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Therefore, I strongly believe that consumers should be wary of "pots of gold" and promises [made] in vain. They should trust solely in what their doctors recommend for each specific case. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: to clean something using water
dictionaryExamples: wash your hands/hair
wash the dishes/clothes/car
These sheets need washing.
I'll wash the jar out and use it again.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We can wash cars to earn some money for the necessary materials. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: to clean yourself, or a part of yourself, with water and usually soap, especially your hands before a meal
dictionaryExamples: Go wash up for dinner now.

sense.def: a machine for washing clothes, sheets and other things made of cloth
dictionaryExamples: Could you empty/load the washing machine, please?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I want to sell [my] washing machine. Key English Test; A2; Greek

sense.def: a black and yellow flying insect that can sting you
dictionaryExamples: There's a wasps' nest in that old tree.
a wasp sting
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We were sitting in the garden and suddenly a wasp entered my T-shirt. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: an unnecessary or wrong use of money, substances, time, energy, abilities, etc.
dictionaryExamples: That meeting achieved absolutely nothing - it was a complete waste of time.
She's been unemployed for two years and it's such a waste of her talents.
This food mixer's been a total waste of money - we never use it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I don't [watch] m[uch] television because I think it's a waste of time. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: unwanted matter or material of any type, often that which is left after useful substances or parts have been removed
dictionaryExamples: hazardous household waste, like leftover paint or insecticides
The group has raised concerns about how nuclear waste would be handled.
Oil spills are common, as is the dumping of toxic waste.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: What I did to get it was send them an article based on some possible solutions to the problem of nuclear waste in my local area. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: Waste material is no longer needed and can be gotten rid of.
dictionaryExamples: The Japanese recycle more than half of their waste paper.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would really like to help you with picking up waste [paper] and glass from people's houses. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: to use too much of something or use something badly when there is a limited amount of it
dictionaryExamples: You waste a lot of water by taking a bath instead of a shower.
Come on, let's get started - we've wasted enough time already.
Don't waste your money on designer jeans.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's nice to hear that you want to go to Colombia and I'm really happy because I can tell you all the details so you won't waste time and money. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to be of a type or quality that someone will not understand or enjoy
dictionaryExamples: Good coffee is wasted on Joe - he prefers instant.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Many older pe[ople] can be heard grumbling that youth is wasted on the young, and I can see their point, though obviously I don't agree. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: a small container that stands on the floor and is used for putting pieces of waste materials in
dictionaryExamples: Toss that plastic wrapper  in the wastebasket.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm sure that who[ever] found [the note pad] t[h]r[e]w it away into the wastebasket because it was so old and dirty. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: to look at something for a period of time
dictionaryExamples: I had dinner and watched TV for a couple of hours.
I watched him get into a taxi.
I got the feeling I was being watched.
I sit by the window and watch people walking past.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She works at the Glade and she watches television at night. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Russian

sense.def: to be careful about something
dictionaryExamples: I have to watch my weight now that I'm not exercising so much.
Watch how you cross the street!
Watch (that) you don't get glue on your fingers.
Watch what you're doing with that knife, Jim, it's sharp.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The odd glass of wine is fine but  watch what you [eat]. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: to be careful
dictionaryExamples: "Watch out!" he shouted, but it was too late - she had knocked over the lamp.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I definitely know that having a cat brings inconvenience, you have to watch out for your curtains, it can scratch your sofa or your hand, but these are so few problems in comparison [with] all the affection [it] can give you. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: a small clock that is worn on a strap around the wrist
dictionaryExamples: My watch seems to have stopped - it says 10:15 but I'm sure it must be later.
He glanced nervously at his watch.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I got 2 watches, flowers and some dresses. Key English Test; A2; Tamil

sense.def: the clear liquid that falls from the sky as rain and is necessary for animal and plant life
dictionaryExamples: hot/cold water
a bottle/drink/glass of water
bottled/mineral/tap water
a drop of water
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You have to bring some food, and a lot of water. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: an area of water, such as the ocean, a lake, or a swimming pool
dictionaryExamples: The water's much warmer today - are you coming for a swim?
Dad, I swam a whole length of the pool under water!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There are a lot of beautiful beaches with clean water. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: If a building has running water, water comes into  it through pipes.
dictionaryExamples: The summer homes on the island have no running water.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is hilarious to think that at the same time people in [the] north of Europe were still living a primitive and uncivilized life not even able to invent an axe, the Romans managed to install running water in their huge houses. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Danish

blocks.phrase: be (like) water off a duck's back

sense.def: If criticisms, insults, etc., are like water off a duck's back to you, they do not affect you at all.
dictionaryExamples: She calls him lazy and useless, but it's like water off a duck's back.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The main lesson I have learned is by looking at some people who have lived alone for most of their life and faced with neither contradiction nor argument, they stay in their ivory tower, so sure of their opinions that whatever you say is like water off a duck's back. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: If you say that an argument doesn't hold water, you mean that it can't be true.
dictionaryExamples: The jury convicted her because her story just didn’t hold water.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example:  It remains to us to prove that the opinions of some scientists are far-fetched and don't hold water. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: water from lakes, rivers, etc. that has no salt in it
dictionaryExamples: These fish live in fresh water.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You find stunning white beaches, clear, fresh water lakes, isolated tropic islands, reef, rainforests, buzzing cities, challenging mountain range, bush, outback - and the desert. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: to have just enough money to live or to continue a business
dictionaryExamples: With extra income from private sponsorship, the club is just about managing to keep its head above water.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I also started to reali[z]e how much she had on her plate, how very little help she had and how, at times, she had to struggle just like me to keep her head above water. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: to pour water on to plants or the soil that they are growing in
dictionaryExamples: I asked my neighbor to water the plants while I'm away.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I can spend a lot of time digging, pulling up weeds, watering my plants and pruning the bushes and so on. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: If food makes your mouth water, it makes you want to eat it, sometimes making your mouth produce liquid.
dictionaryExamples: The smells from the kitchen are making my mouth water.

sense.def: water, especially from a river or stream, dropping from a higher to a lower point, sometimes from a great height
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We walked for an hour and arrived at the waterfall. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: not allowing water to go through
dictionaryExamples: Canvas boots are all right but they're not as waterproof as leather.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Also deck shoes and a waterproof jacket for sailing; but besides that will I need any thing else? First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: to raise your hand and move it from side to side in order to attract someone's attention or to say goodbye
dictionaryExamples: I waved to/at him, and he waved back.
She was so mad she wouldn't even wave goodbye to us.
She waves her hands around a lot when she's talking.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She waved at me and I smiled. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: to move from side to side in the air or make something move this way
dictionaryExamples: The long grass waved in the breeze.
He started waving his arms around wildly.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I can picture myself standing in front of the "Casa Prosada," waving my arms and cheering with all the other patriots. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: a line of higher water that moves across the surface of an area of water, especially the ocean
dictionaryExamples: At night, I listened to the sound of the waves breaking/crashing against the shore.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I already know you surf and the waves at Reserva will be huge this weekend [so] we will surely surf together.  Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: the pattern in which some types of energy, such as sound, light and heat, are spread or carried
dictionaryExamples: radio waves
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Indeed, it is thought that using a mobile phone may cause brain damage owing to magnetic waves. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: a group of people or things that arrive or happen together or in a short period of time
dictionaryExamples: There has been a wave of robberies in the region.
Another wave of people  flowed into the theater.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: These people, who belong mostly to the middle class, and some other[s] like explorers [...] or youngsters seeking some adventure, produce the big wave of tourists to different countries. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: when you suddenly feel an emotion
dictionaryExamples: She felt a sudden wave of sadness.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As he counted the money, a wave of shame and horror hit Berthold. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: to cause problems by asking difficult questions or criticizing
dictionaryExamples: He has earned a reputation for making waves during political campaigns.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If we don't want to regret anything, it is time we started to make waves by s[c]rutinizing our history. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Turkish

sense.def: when you raise your hand and move it from side to side in order to attract someone's attention or to say hello or goodbye
dictionaryExamples: She gave a little wave as the train left.

sense.def: how you do something
dictionaryExamples: There are many ways of solving the problem.
That's not the way to do it - let me show you.
This method hasn't worked, so let's try your way.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think it's the best way to relax. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: the route you take to get from one place to another
dictionaryExamples: Do you know the way to the train station?
I've only been living in Chicago for a couple of weeks so I don't really know my way around yet.
We'll have to stop for gas on the way to the airport.
Can you find your own way out of the building?
The bus stopped for us to eat lunch, but within half an hour we were on our way way again.
The fastest way through town is by the old highway.
Many people have lost their way in the forest.
Somehow the dog found its way home.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The shortest way to get there is going along Sarmiento Avenue. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: used when you say something new or on a different subject
dictionaryExamples: I think we've discussed everything we need to - by the way, what time is it?
Oh, by the way, my name's Julie.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: By the way, I want to buy a raincoat for my brother. Key English Test; A2; Farsi

sense.def: the direction in which something is facing or travels
dictionaryExamples: "Which way does the room face?" "North."
This bus is going the wrong way.
a one-way street
Which way up should this box be?
The numbers are the wrong way around - it should be 71, not 17.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Although he had told us he knew this address, he went [the] wrong way. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: a distance or a period of time
dictionaryExamples: We walked a long way yesterday.
Thanksgiving seems like it's a long way away/off.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like this best because [it] is not a long way from home. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: used to tell someone that something is impossible
dictionaryExamples: I'm sorry, but there's no way we can help you.
No way will she agree to you leaving early.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Don't worry, there is no way I'm going to miss it! Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: the manner in which a person lives
dictionaryExamples: Sleeping in hotels three or four nights a week is not an ideal way of life.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He told me about his hobbies, his way of life and especially about his love [of] learning languages. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: used to talk about two possibilities where the result will be the same
dictionaryExamples: You can get there by train or bus - either way it'll take an hour.
He might have to resign or he might be given a desk job, but either way, his career is effectively over.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If that doesn't work, you can ask them to talk to your friends' parents so you could all go together. Either way, I know you will have lots of fun this summer. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: in some way that is not stated
dictionaryExamples: One way or another these bills have to be paid.
Everyone at the party was related in one way or another.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All of them made a big difference [to] our personal life and have affected it one way or another. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: in any way that is possible
dictionaryExamples: We have to make a decision one way or the other about what needs to be done.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Even if we choose not to use computers personally, many of our transactions with society work through [a] computer system one way or the other. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: happening in the opposite way
dictionaryExamples: I thought the older people would be more offended than the young people, but it was the other way around.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They are controlling us and not the other way around. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: to get to a place
dictionaryExamples: We slowly made our way down the river.
It's getting late - we should make our way home soon.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She made her way slowly to the waiting room and patiently waited for the train to arrive. First Certificate in English; B2; Azerbaijani

sense.def: the complete distance
dictionaryExamples: They ran all the way to school.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I drove all the way to Bergen in only one day. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

blocks.phrase: in a way or  in some/many ways

sense.def: used to say that you think something is partly true
dictionaryExamples: In a way, I would prefer it if they didn't come because it would mean extra work.
In some  ways it would be better if we met on Monday rather than Wednesday.
He was a remarkable politician in many ways.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think that many people would like [stores] to be open all the time, and it might be good in some ways. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: when one thing or feeling changes to a different one
dictionaryExamples: My excitement gave way to fear when I drove a car for the first time.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The feeling of anger they first had disappeared and gave way to a feeling of disappointment. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: the manner in which someone behaves or thinks, or in which something happens
dictionaryExamples: Don't be alarmed - it's just his way.
He looked at me in a sinister way.
It's amazing the way she manages to stay so calm.
The way he was shouting, you'd have thought he was badly hurt.
It's always the way - either I've got nothing to do or way too much.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To my way of thinking, despite all the problems I have mentioned, this company will suc[c]eed. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: similarly
dictionaryExamples: In the same way, there are many citizens who feel unprotected by the police.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the same way, grandmothers may be shocked when seeing their little children wearing extravagant clothes or really short skirts. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French

blocks.phrase: in no way/not in any way

sense.def: not at all
dictionaryExamples: This is in no way your fault.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This magazine will be loved by students as it will help them learn English in the best way and in no way will students find it boring. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: as a type of something
dictionaryExamples: He sent me some flowers by way of apology.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The Academy however provided nothing whatsoever by way of entertainment, though with a group of interesting young people and a little imagination this should not be a pro[b]lem. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Dutch

sense.def: to get what you want, although it might upset other people
dictionaryExamples: She always gets her own way in the end.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They are provided with what they desire, and [the] majority of them are used to getting their own way. International English Language Testing System; C1; Thai

sense.def: to do what is easiest in a difficult situation
dictionaryExamples: I know you don't approve of his working methods, but why not take the easy way out this time and agree to his request?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On the other hand you cannot survive without your pay-check and to be able to both make a car[ee]r and have the time to be green, sometimes you just have to take the easy way out. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Danish

sense.def: the space needed for a particular movement or action
dictionaryExamples: "Sorry, am I in your way? I'll move."
If you don't move that vase out of the way, it might get broken.
Don't let your new friends get in the way of your studies.
I couldn't see the stage because there was a pillar in the way.
Please make way so the ambulance can get by.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As Mark Twain once said "Don't let school get in the way of your education." Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to be successful and make progress in your work
dictionaryExamples: He managed to make his way in the film industry.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For each one of the famous sportsmen we re[cog]ni[z]e on television or in the newspapers, there are thousands of hopeful youngsters trying to make their way to the top. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

blocks.phrase: go out of your way to do sth

sense.def: to try very hard to do something pleasant for someone
dictionaryExamples: He went out of his way to make us feel welcome.

blocks.phrase: get/have sth out of the way

sense.def: to finish a task or to get rid of something unpleasant
dictionaryExamples: I'll go shopping when I've got this essay out of the way.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was a joyful reunion and everybody was grateful to have all misunderstandings out of the way and to be one big family once more. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: used to say that someone or something does something to a large degree
dictionaryExamples: They celebrate birthdays in a big way.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Tourism helps Greece's national economy - which is not at its best - in a big way. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to be already happening
dictionaryExamples: Building work is already under way.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Sociologists are well-aware of the fact and experiments are under way to counterbalance these disadvantages. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: If something gives way, it falls because it is not strong enough to support the weight on top of it.
dictionaryExamples: Suddenly the ground gave way under me.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Fred's voice trailed off as he felt his legs give way beneath him. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Chinese

sense.def: to be replaced by someone or something
dictionaryExamples: They knocked down the old houses to make way for a new hotel.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Local markets are broken down to make way for shopping malls, which sell items for the brand conscious population of today. International English Language Testing System; C2; Hindi

sense.def: If something paves the way for something else, it makes the other thing possible.
dictionaryExamples: Scientists hope that data from the probe will pave the way for a more detailed exploration of Mars.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Many celebrities engage actively in UN projects and pave the way for others to contribute. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Bulgarian

sense.def: to learn something by experiencing a lot of problems or difficulty
dictionaryExamples: He doesn’t want to take my advice, so I guess he’ll have to learn the hard way.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you don't know the past, you're liable to live through it again as instead of deriving the lessons from someone else's experiences, you'll have to learn them the hard way, by trial and error. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: to move carefully through a crowded place, changing direction in order to avoid people or things
dictionaryExamples: She threaded her way through the crowd.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And if I thread my way through the crowd along the street, I can find almost all things I want to buy, from inexpensive souvenirs to internationally known brands of suits.

sense.def: used as the subject of the verb to refer to the speaker and at least one other person when considered together or as a group
dictionaryExamples: Can we all go to the swimming pool this afternoon?
If you don't hurry up we'll be late.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After dinner we want to go shopping. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Bengali

sense.def: used to refer to people generally
dictionaryExamples: The world in which we live today is very different.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Why can't we live without computers? First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: not physically strong
dictionaryExamples: He was feeling weak after his cancer treatment.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm very worried because Boby isn't a big dog, and in this period he was very weak because he [had] some problems with a leg so I hope that he is fine! Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: not good at something
dictionaryExamples: She reads well, but her spelling is weak.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Listening is my weak point so I have to improve. Preliminary English Test; B1; Japanese

sense.def: not powerful, or not having a strong character
dictionaryExamples: a weak leader/government
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At the beginning of the story, [Mary] seemed to be a weak person, but in the end she demonstrated that she could overcome her fears in order to protect someone. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: A weak reason, argument, or excuse is one that you do not have enough proof to support.
dictionaryExamples: He gave the weakest excuse for why he was late.

sense.def: not able to support heavy things
dictionaryExamples: a weak bridge

sense.def: containing little taste or alcohol
dictionaryExamples: weak coffee/beer

sense.def: difficult to see or hear
dictionaryExamples: He spoke in a weak voice.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I could hardly see with the weak light of the candle and I couldn't remember the last time I had used it. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: likely to fail
dictionaryExamples: a weak economy
a weak team
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A very difficult aspect currently is our weak economy, we could nearly speak of a recession. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swiss German

sense.def: to become less strong or powerful, or to make someone or something less strong or powerful
dictionaryExamples: A number of factors have weakened the economy.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If we get rid of the factories to save the river, it is obvious that our economy will be weakened. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Korean

sense.def: to become less certain or determined about a decision, or to make someone less determined
dictionaryExamples: I told him I wouldn't give him any more money, but then I weakened.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I felt my resistance weaken and at the end of our conversation I said that she could come over for a night but just this night, as I tried to make it very clear to her. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: when someone or something is not strong or powerful
dictionaryExamples: Asking for help is not a sign of weakness.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I believe that I'll be able to cover my physical weakness with my experience and knowledge. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: a particular part or quality of someone or something that is not good or effective
dictionaryExamples: There are definite weaknesses in their security arrangements.
His main weakness as a manager is his inability to delegate.
The later novels show none of the weaknesses of his earlier work.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: However, I have to complain about a few weaknesses in this festival. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: to like a particular thing or person very much
dictionaryExamples: She has a real weakness for ice cream.

sense.def: a large amount of money or valuable possessions that someone has
dictionaryExamples: During a successful business career, she accumulated a great amount of wealth.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On the other hand, having a mobile phone can also create social distinctions between people as it can [be] a sign of wealth. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: a large amount of something good
dictionaryExamples: a wealth of experience/information
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: One of the advantages often mentioned is that old people have a wealth of experience, gained throughout life. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: rich
dictionaryExamples: He's a very wealthy man.
With its natural resources it is potentially a very wealthy country.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But how can anyone satisfy a wealthy woman like her without giving her an expensive present? First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: any object used in fighting or war, such as a gun, bomb, sword, etc.
dictionaryExamples: chemical/nuclear/biological weapons
The youths were dragged from their car and searched for weapons.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Technology is used [to] create new types of weapons. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to have clothing, jewelery, etc. on your body
dictionaryExamples: Tracey is wearing a simple black dress.
What are you wearing to Caroline's wedding?
Some musicians don't like to wear rings when they're playing.
He wears glasses for reading.
She wears very little makeup.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She likes to wear new clothes. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Russian

sense.def: to arrange or grow your hair in a particular way
dictionaryExamples: She usually wears her hair in a ponytail.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example:  I now wear my long hair loose and I dyed it black. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: to show a particular emotion on your face.
dictionaryExamples: He was wearing a smile/frown.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She was wearing a big smile on her face that reflected happiness. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: If a feeling or explanation starts to wear thin, it becomes weaker or harder to accept.
dictionaryExamples: I've warned you several times about being late and my patience is wearing thin.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Hardly could they fight against others, when their own convictions had started to wear thin. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: If a feeling or effect wears off, it gradually disappears.
dictionaryExamples: The injection the dentist gave me is starting to wear off.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And Jim, has his pas[s]ion for you finally worn off? First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: to use something so much that it is damaged and cannot be used any more, or to become damaged in this way
dictionaryExamples: He's already worn out two pairs of shoes this year.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My shoes are worn out too! I have to get new ones.Preliminary English Test; B1; French

blocks.phrasalVerb: wear sb out or wear out sb

sense.def: to make someone extremely tired
dictionaryExamples: Standing up all day is wearing me out.
They were all worn out by the time the game was over.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This does not mean that we have to spend hours in the gym and get home worn out. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: very tired
dictionaryExamples: You look weary, my love.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On the other hand, if we choose to sleep, it means that we are willing to inject some power in our weary bodies and minds. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: bored with something or someone
dictionaryExamples: She grew weary of the children and their games.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The young man was getting weary of being rejected like this, but he was still hoping that she would open her heart to him some day. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: the conditions in the air above the Earth such as wind, rain or temperature, especially at a particular time over a particular area
dictionaryExamples: bad/good/cold/dry/hot/stormy/warm/wet weather
The weather in the hills can change very quickly, so dress in layers.
We're going to have a picnic, weather permitting.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I need it because the weather is cold. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: to feel ill
dictionaryExamples: I'm feeling a little under the weather this morning.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Why do we listen to music every time we are under the weather?  As far as I am concerned, music plays a key role in my life. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: a description of what the weather will be like
dictionaryExamples: Have you heard the weather forecast for tomorrow?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The weather forecast is not so good for the next two days: rain and wind. Preliminary English Test; B1; Swedish

sense.def: a camera that records moving pictures and sounds and allows these to be shown on the Internet as they happen
dictionaryExamples: I see my grandchildren via the webcam.

sense.def: a part of a Web site that can be read on a computer screen
dictionaryExamples: There is a Web page with this information.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can find the art class information [on] her web page. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: a set of pages of information on the Internet about a particular subject that have been published by the same person or organization and that often contain color pictures, video, and sound
dictionaryExamples: For more information about other Cambridge titles, visit our Web site at www.cambridge.org.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So, don't wait more and [phone] Peter Morison, from Visualmarket Web site or ask for an interview with him [at] the following number 56.41.913024. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: a marriage ceremony and any celebrations such as a meal or a party that follow it
dictionaryExamples: a wedding cake/dress/invitation/present/reception
Do you know the date of Cathy and Matthew's wedding?
It was their twenty-fifth wedding anniversary last week.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Some couples prefer to [have] a traditional wedding in an old village. Preliminary English Test; B1; Greek

sense.def: the day of the week after Tuesday and before Thursday
dictionaryExamples: Did you say the meeting is on Wednesday?
The restaurant is always closed on Wednesdays.
Wednesday would be a good day for us to go running.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I come every Wednesday. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Hungarian

sense.def: a wild plant that you do not want to grow in your yard, garden, or field
dictionaryExamples: Dandelions are common weeds.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A loose shutter was tapping against the wall, he walked over to close it and from the window he saw the garden overgrown with weeds. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: a period of seven days
dictionaryExamples: last/this/next week
We go to a restaurant about once/twice a week.
Don't do any sports for a week or two.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She visits her parents once a week. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Hungarian

sense.def: the five days from Monday to Friday when people usually go to work or school
dictionaryExamples: I don't go out much during the week.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My mother has to work during the week. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Spanish

sense.def: one of the five days from Monday to Friday when people usually go to work or school
dictionaryExamples: This road is very busy on weekdays.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I can write at the weekends, because I have no time on weekdays. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: Saturday and Sunday, or Friday evening until Sunday night; the part of the week when many people do not work
dictionaryExamples: Do you have anything planned for the weekend?
This/Next weekend we're going to see some friends.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On weekend[s] she goes to visit her uncle. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Kurdish

sense.def: happening once a week or every week
dictionaryExamples: a weekly magazine/report
a twice-weekly meeting
The fire alarm has a weekly test/is tested weekly.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I also read magazines and newspapers to [get] information about daily and weekly events. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: to cry, usually because you are sad
dictionaryExamples: She covered her face with her hands and wept.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Still weeping, Mary felt a tiny little hand on her arm and stared at it in astonishment. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: to have a heaviness of a stated amount, or to measure the heaviness of an object
dictionaryExamples: How much do you weigh?
His backpack must weigh more than 20 pounds.
She weighs herself every week on the bathroom scale.
Your luggage must be weighed before it is put on the aircraft.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can [see] monkeys that weigh only 100g. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: to consider something carefully, especially in order to make a decision
dictionaryExamples: He needs to weigh  the pros and cons of going to college.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Having weighed the pros and cons, I thought you [ought] to be conscious of the fact that... you're working too hard. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: the amount that something or someone weighs
dictionaryExamples: He's about average height and weight.
I need to lose a little weight.
Doug has gained a lot of weight recently.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So let me describe Fabian: he has brown hair and his weight is about 75 kg.  Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: the quality of being heavy
dictionaryExamples: The shelf collapsed under the weight of the books.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The weight of the snow broke the branches of the trees. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: something that  is heavy
dictionaryExamples: Try not to lift heavy weights.
I lift weights twice a week at the gym.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [...] my long training periods in lifting weights. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to work as hard as other people in a group
dictionaryExamples: The rest of the team complained that Sarah wasn't pulling her weight.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For instance, before your kin get all nice and comfortable, you could ask them to pull their weight around the house by doing a few jobs. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to be considered important and effective in influencing someone
dictionaryExamples: His opinions carry a lot of weight with the scientific community.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It has become increasingly important to strive for near perfection in every move they make, the pursuit of excellence therefore carrying more weight than ever and leading to strenuous tr[ai]ning programs. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swiss German

sense.def: very strange and unusual, unexpected or not natural
dictionaryExamples: Her boyfriend's a little weird, but she's all right.
That's weird - I thought I left my keys on the table, but they're not there.
I had a weird dream last night.
He has a really weird schedule this semester.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She was hearing all sorts of weird noises. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: said as a greeting to someone arriving at a place
dictionaryExamples: Welcome - please come in.
Welcome home/back - we've missed you!
Welcome to Houston.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Wendy, welcome to my town. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: to greet someone who has arrived in a  place
dictionaryExamples: Both families were there to welcome us.
The visitors to the college were warmly welcomed by the Dean.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: First, the president welcomed me and gave me my membership card. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: to be pleased about something and encourage or support it
dictionaryExamples: The decision has been widely welcomed.
I would welcome your advice.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The time will arrive [when] all of us will accept and welcome this "beautiful machine"! [the computer]First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: said as a polite answer when someone thanks you for doing something
dictionaryExamples: "It was very nice of you to help." "You're welcome."

sense.def: If you are welcome, people are pleased that you are there.
dictionaryExamples: You will always be welcome here.
She makes us (feel) welcome whenever we visit her.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You know that you are very welcome in my country. Preliminary English Test; B1; Arabic

sense.def: used to tell someone that they can certainly do something, if they want to
dictionaryExamples: Anyone who is interested is welcome to come along.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You're very welcome to join too if you want. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: If something is welcome, people are pleased about it and want it to happen.
dictionaryExamples: a welcome change
Your comments are always welcome.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And, since all these new things only make our life easier, technology is welcome. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: when someone is met and spoken to in a friendly way when they arrive in a place
dictionaryExamples: They were given a warm welcome.
She referred to his previous visit in her welcome speech.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Bertha, Once again I want to thank you very much for your hospitality and the warm welcome you gave me. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: to stay somewhere too long so that people want you to leave
dictionaryExamples: I don't want to outstay my welcome.

sense.def: Someone's welfare is their health and happiness.
dictionaryExamples: We were concerned for our parents’ welfare when we heard about the storm in Florida.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To take care of the visitor's wishes must be a priority: his welfare has to be enforced by structural measures (facilities, services, activities) and cultural ones. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: help, especially money, given by the government to people who are poor or do not have jobs
dictionaryExamples: She works in child welfare.
The family had to go on welfare.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The fact is, many people now are on welfare and that keep them quiet. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: in a successful or satisfactory way
dictionaryExamples: I thought the team played well.
He's doing very well in school.
The store sells well-made clothes.
They took two hours to discuss the plans and considered it time well spent.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I play guitar very well and I love rock! Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: in addition (to)
dictionaryExamples: Are you going to invite Steve as well?
They have lived in the United States as well as Britain.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dylma goes to school every day and work[s] as well. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: in a complete way or as much as possible
dictionaryExamples: Stir the mixture well.
I know him very well.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I live in the capital city. [...] I know it very well and it will be [a] pleasure to guide you around. Preliminary English Test; B1; Slovak

sense.def: used to say that something is likely to be true
dictionaryExamples: She might well be the best person to ask.
He could well be at Michelle's house.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Laura could well imagine  [that] she would stand opposite the examiners and not answer any question in the right way. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: used to emphasize some adjectives
dictionaryExamples: The police are well aware of the situation.
The museum is well worth a visit.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Finally I would like to recommend a visit to Lampton Castle; in addition to the paintings and furniture there is now a new collection of musical instruments, which is well worth seeing. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: used to emphasize some prepositions
dictionaryExamples: The results are well above/below what we expected.
Keep well away from the edge of the cliff.
It cost well over $100.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The hospital received well over 80% of the profits, and that as you can see is much more than just 60%. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: If you may/might as well do something, it will not spoil the situation if you do that thing.
dictionaryExamples: If we're not waiting for Karen, we might as well go now.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I might as well go with her and if you like, you can join us too. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Turkish

sense.def: used to say that something is not a suitable or practical thing to do
dictionaryExamples: I couldn't very well tell her while he was there.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I couldn't very well tell her that without my diaries, I'd be lost and not know who I was. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: to intend to be helpful or kind but cause problems instead
dictionaryExamples: He means well, but he keeps trying to help with things he doesn't really understand.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Although these fans might mean well, in many cases they do not appear to reali[z]e that their "heroes" perhaps would like to be left alone. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: healthy; not sick
dictionaryExamples: "How are you?" "Very well, thanks."
He hasn't been too well lately.
When she came home from school she really didn't look well.
I'm sorry you're sick - I hope you get well soon.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: How are you? I'm very well. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Bengali

sense.def: everything is in a good or acceptable state
dictionaryExamples: I hope all is well with Jack.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I hope all's well. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: used to say it is good or useful that something happened in a particular way
dictionaryExamples: It's just as well we brought an umbrella.
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: All these things more than compensated for there not really being anything much to do in the evenings.  Maybe that was just as well, because both the travel costs and my own pocket money expenditure had exceed the amount of money I had intended to spend. 
 Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: used to show that you do not agree with something or that you are annoyed about something
dictionaryExamples: It's all very well for her to say everything's fine, she doesn't have to live here.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: That's all very well for most of the people but according to my desires [i]t's not enough. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: used at the beginning of a sentence to pause slightly or to express doubt or disagreement
dictionaryExamples: "You'll go, won't you?"  "Well, I'm not sure."
Well, what should we do now?
"Who was that?"  "Well, I'm afraid I can't remember her name."
Well, after that we went camping in the mountains.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Well, my friend, I have just seen this film but I can see it again. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: used to say that a situation cannot be changed although it might be disappointing
dictionaryExamples: Oh well, it doesn't matter; I can always buy another one.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I always dreamed [of going] sailing, but not even a little boat [is] left, some other people [have] already booked them!  Oh well. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: A well-balanced diet or meal  includes all the different types of food that the body needs to be healthy.
dictionaryExamples: I try to have a well-balanced diet.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So my advice for you would be to try and have some break times during the day, [do]  some sports and follow a well-balanced diet. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: Well-balanced people are calm and have good judgment.
dictionaryExamples: She's very well-balanced considering her past.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Linda has a good temper, is well-balanced and is able to cope with unforeseen or complicated situations. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: when someone is healthy, happy, and comfortable
dictionaryExamples: I found that yoga increased my sense of well-being.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The beautiful countryside which surrounds the fields can generate a feeling of well-being and make exercise more pleasant. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: having a large, strong body
dictionaryExamples: He was a well-built man, in his forties.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When I was twenty three years old, I was married to a handsome, well-built business man. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: wearing attractive, good-quality clothes
dictionaryExamples: She is a very well-dressed woman.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is a party for the students who take part in the conference, so you do not need to be well-dressed. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: having had a good education
dictionaryExamples: We have some very well-educated employees in the department.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Increasing numbers of well-educated young people are compelled to stay at home. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: having plenty of good quality equipment
dictionaryExamples: He has a very well-equipped kitchen.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There is a well-equipped gym which is supervised by experienced staff. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: knowing a lot of useful information
dictionaryExamples: A well-informed visitor to our museum brought this error to our attention.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They are people with a wide range of interests, thus we should try to keep them well-informed. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: famous
dictionaryExamples: a well-known actor/artist/film star/singer
a well-known face/voice
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would like to suggest [we] invite some well-known artists to next year's festival. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: having a lot of money
dictionaryExamples: His well-off parents sent him to a very expensive school.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you belong to a well-off family then you are considered lucky, but if you are not this, good luck to you. International English Language Testing System; C1; Tagalog

sense.def: working in an effective and successful way because of good organization
dictionaryExamples: She's always extremely well-organized at work.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The events that I had attended were well-organized and were highly entertaining in many ways. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: earning a lot of money
dictionaryExamples: a well-paid job
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [She had] an interesting and well-paid job in Paris as a fashion model. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: having suitable experience or formal qualifications
dictionaryExamples: He seems well-qualified for the job.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: That is why fore[ig]n employers look for well-qualified Polish specialists. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: the direction that you face to see the sun go down
dictionaryExamples: The points of the compass are North, South, East and West.
The sun rises in the east and sets in the west.

sense.def: the part of an area that is further toward the west than the rest
dictionaryExamples: We live in the west of the city.
Most of the country will be dry tomorrow, but the west will have some rain.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It [is] situated in the west of [the] town and it is near the sea. Key English Test; A2; Italian

sense.def: the countries of North America and western Europe
dictionaryExamples: There has been concern in/throughout the West about the effects of this measure.
East-West relations

sense.def: in or forming the west part of something
dictionaryExamples: the west coast of Canada
a country in west Africa
the west wing of the White House
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I most enjoyed Bergen, which is [o]n the west coast of Norway. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: toward the west
dictionaryExamples: We traveled west.
They live in a suburb four miles west of Philadelphia.

sense.def: in or from the west part of an area
dictionaryExamples: western Europe
California and other western states
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is in the western part of Kyoto. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: relating to countries in the west part of the world, especially North America and countries in the west of Europe
dictionaryExamples: western opinion/culture
a Western-educated engineer
western medicine
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nowadays, most young people would like to wear suits and dresses like Westerners because, they're more interested in western culture. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: covered in water or another liquid
dictionaryExamples: a wet floor
a wet umbrella
wet hair
My bike got wet in the rain.
I had to cycle in the rain and got soaking  wet.
You poor thing - you're all  wet.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [Yester]day I was at the swimming pool and I g[o]t out with wet hair. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Polish

sense.def: describes weather or periods of time when rain falls
dictionaryExamples: We've had wet weather all week.
This is the first wet day for two months.
The presentation will take place indoors if it's wet.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The last thing I bought was a jacket because of the cold and wet weather here. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: describes paint, ink, or a similar substance when it has not had time to dry and become hard
dictionaryExamples: The paint's still wet.
a sign saying 'Wet paint!'

sense.def: a very large sea mammal that breathes air through a hole at the top of its head
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You could also go to Cordoba [which] is a place similar to Tandil or to [...] Patagonia to fish and see the whales. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: used to ask for information about something
dictionaryExamples: What did you wear?
What happened after I left?
What caused the accident?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: What do you think about that? Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; French

sense.def: used when suggesting or offering something to someone
dictionaryExamples: What about a trip to the zoo this afternoon?
"Coffee, Sarah?" "No, thanks." "What about you, Kate?"
When can we meet? What about next week?
What about getting a pizza?
What about Luis - should we invite him?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would love to see the film. What about Friday? Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: used to refer to something without naming it
dictionaryExamples: Do you know what I mean?
She wouldn't tell me what he said.
What I like most about her is her honesty.
The letter showed clearly what they were planning.
I can't decide what to do next.
Have you thought about what to send as a present?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I don't know what to do now. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: used to ask for someone's opinion on a particular subject
dictionaryExamples: What  about Ava - is she nice?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I also enjoy shopping for shoes, what about you? Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: used to ask about something that could happen in the future, especially something bad
dictionaryExamples: What if the train's late?
What if you don't pass your test?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: What if the children were in trouble? Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: used to ask how things are with someone
dictionaryExamples: What's up? Nice to see you again.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Hi Teresa What's up? I am good. Preliminary English Test; B1; Turkish

sense.def: used to ask about the reason for something
dictionaryExamples: What are these tools for?
What are you doing that for?
"We need a bigger car." "What for?"
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: People love spending hours in their stuffy cars, [gett]ing stuck in traffic jams and breathing polluted air. What for? First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: used to add something surprising or interesting to what you have just said
dictionaryExamples: They turned up nearly an hour late, and what's more, they didn't bring anything!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: What is more, I will have an opportunity to visit the most exotic countries. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: used to talk about the reasons for a particular situation, especially a bad or difficult situation
dictionaryExamples: I'm tired, what with traveling all day yesterday and sleeping badly.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The energy of a crowd like that is amazing, what with people jumping up and down, singing their lungs out and pushing each other around. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: used to ask for information about something
dictionaryExamples: What time is it?
What books did you buy?
What size shoes do you wear?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: What time [would] you like to come? Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Pashto

sense.def: used to give your opinion, especially when you have strong feelings about something
dictionaryExamples: What nonsense!
What a mess!
What an awful day!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Last Saturday we decided to watch the film "Pinocchio" by Roberto Benigni. What a beautiful soundtrack!  What an interesting fable! Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: anything or everything
dictionaryExamples: The children are allowed to do whatever they want.
I eat whatever I want and I still don't seem to gain weight.
Whatever I say I always seem to get it wrong.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think people should wear whatever they want to. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: used to say that what happens is not important because it does not change a situation
dictionaryExamples: Whatever happens, you know that I'll stand by you.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Whatever you decide, I hope you enjoy a wonderful summer. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: or other things of the same kind
dictionaryExamples: If you need to wash, or whatever, we can meet you later.

sense.def: used to say that what happens is not important because it does not change a situation
dictionaryExamples: We'll go whatever the weather.
Whatever else may be said of him, Mr. Meese is not scared of a fight.
But whatever the reason, most people who move from one region to another are under 35 years old.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Whatever you decide, I hope you enjoy a wonderful summer. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: a plant whose yellowish brown grain is used for making flour, or the grain itself
dictionaryExamples: wheat fields
Wheat is an important crop for millions of people across the world.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [In the painting, a man and woman] are sleeping in a wheat field. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: a circular object fixed under a vehicle so that it moves smoothly over the ground
dictionaryExamples: My bike needs a new wheel.
He lost control of his car when the front/rear wheel hit a rock.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I ride my bicycle [every day], but now its front wheel is broken. Preliminary English Test; B1; Polish

sense.def: a steering wheel
dictionaryExamples: You should keep both hands on the wheel when driving.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On the continent Barbara and I took turns at the wheel and early next morning we reached the Spanish border. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: a chair with wheels used by someone who cannot walk
dictionaryExamples: My brother uses a wheelchair.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the hospital, I was sentenced to be confined to [a] wheelchair for the rest of my life. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: used to ask at what time something happened or will happen
dictionaryExamples: "I did tell you about it." "When? I don't remember."
When's your birthday?
When did he leave?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When are you coming [to] my house? Key English Test; A2; Japanese

sense.def: used to say at what time something happened or will happen
dictionaryExamples: I found it when I was cleaning out the cupboards.
We'll go when you're ready.
She was only twenty when she had her first baby.
He was really shocked when I told him.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Anyway, when I finish my exam I can visit you or you visit me. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Polish

sense.def: used to say something that is surprising after what has already been said
dictionaryExamples: He says he doesn't have any money when in fact he has thousands of dollars in his account.
I don't understand how he can say that everything's fine when it's so obvious that it's not.
Why is she training to be a teacher when she doesn't even like children?
How can you say you don't like something when you've never even tried it!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In your advertisement it was said that I would find stars and artists from around the world, when, in fact, they were from only six countries. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: every time or any time
dictionaryExamples: Whenever I go there they seem to be out.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I read whenever I can, specially at night. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: every time it is possible
dictionaryExamples: I try to use olive oil whenever possible.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My friends have always regarded me as a cheerful, active girl, who is glad to help out whenever possible. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: every time or any time
dictionaryExamples: "Will it be okay if I do it tomorrow?" "Sure, whenever."
Do it in a spare moment at the weekend or whenever - it really doesn't matter.

sense.def: used to ask about the place or position of someone or something
dictionaryExamples: Where does he live?
Where are my car keys?
"I put them on your desk." "Where? I can't see them."
Where did you put my umbrella?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Where is the college? Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Akan

sense.def: what someone thinks about you, how they expect you to behave, and how they are likely to behave
dictionaryExamples: He didn’t even send me a birthday card, so I guess I know where I stand.

sense.def: what your opinion is about something
dictionaryExamples: The Senator has made it clear where she stands on these issues.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: From where I stand, some action must be taken urgently because the problems are constantly exacerbating. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: at, in or to a place or position
dictionaryExamples: I've been meaning to ask you where you get your hair cut.
I like to have him next to me where I can keep an eye on him.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I need to know where I can study French. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Slovak

sense.def: used when referring to a particular stage in a process or activity
dictionaryExamples: You reach a point in any project where you just want to get the thing finished.
I've reached the stage where I just don't care anymore.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We've come to a point where we have forgotten how to read or talk to each other. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: used to ask in what place or area someone or something is
dictionaryExamples: Whereabouts does he live?

sense.def: the place where someone or something is
dictionaryExamples: His whereabouts are unknown.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: However, his whereabouts have been unknown for 6 years. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: compared with the fact that
dictionaryExamples: He must be about sixty, whereas his wife looks about thirty.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For example, it takes two hours by plane from Switzerland to Spain, whereas it takes approximately one day by train. First Certificate in English; B2; Swiss German

sense.def: by which
