dictionaryExamples: They've introduced a system whereby people can pay back their loans slowly over time.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Those in favor of sep[a]rating the genders quote studies whereby boys demonstrate better results in school without the distraction of having the fairer sex around. International English Language Testing System; C2; Farsi

sense.def: in or to any or every place
dictionaryExamples: You can sit wherever you like.
Wherever you choose to live there are always going to be disadvantages.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I will be able to take you wherever you want in [a] matter of minutes. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: every time it is possible
dictionaryExamples: Wherever possible I use honey instead of sugar.
We try to sell local fruit and vegetables wherever possible.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We can work together [in a] number of ways, for e[xample], we can plant trees wherever possible and we can place bins [i]n the necessary areas which will help the public to dispose [of] waste items. International English Language Testing System; B2; Tamil

sense.def: used especially in reporting questions and when expressing doubt to mean if
dictionaryExamples: I wasn't sure whether you'd like it.
She asked me whether I was interested in working for her.
I doubt whether it'll work.
It all depends on whether or not she has the time.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's very expensive and I'm so broke that I don't know whether I can afford to buy one. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: used to talk about a choice between two or more possibilities
dictionaryExamples: I'm going, whether she likes it or not.
Someone has to tell her, whether it's you or me.
Let's face it - you're going to be late whether you go by bus or train.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I don't know whether to stay or to go. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: used to ask or talk about a choice between two or more things
dictionaryExamples: Which jacket do you prefer?
Which time is better for you - 12:15 or 12:45?
I don't know which one to choose.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Which car did he use, the McLaren or the Ferrari? Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: used to ask or talk about a choice between two or more things
dictionaryExamples: Which of these do you like best?
Which is the best way to the station?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Which would you recommend and why? Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: used at the beginning of a relative clause to show what thing is being referred to
dictionaryExamples: These are problems which we all know about.
You know that little Italian restaurant - the one which I mentioned in my letter?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like to wear clothes which are black or blue. Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German

sense.def: used to give extra information about something
dictionaryExamples: The book, which includes a map, gives you all the information you need about Budapest.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Turning to the end-of-conference party, it is going to be held in a nearby buffet restaurant, Valentine's, which has good quality food and reasonable prices. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: used after a preposition to show what thing is being referred to
dictionaryExamples: Is that the film in which she sings?
The death of his son was an experience from which he never fully recovered.
It isn't a subject to which I devote a great deal of thought.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: According to your advertisement in a language magazine you have a vacancy in your campsites, in which I am very interested. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: used when you give an opinion or comment about what you have just said
dictionaryExamples: He showed me around the town, which I thought was very nice of him.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am very interested in being able to help [o]n such a project, which I think is a very good one. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: any of a group of similar things
dictionaryExamples: Let's go out on Thursday or Friday - you choose whichever day is best for you.
You can have whichever bedroom you want in the apartment.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm very [pleased], because in this way, I can buy whichever DVD I want! Preliminary English Test; B1; Greek

sense.def: used to say that what happens is not important because it does not change a situation
dictionaryExamples: It's going to be expensive whichever way you do it.
Whichever option we choose there'll be disadvantages.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In Japan, there are two major style[s] of tea. One is Omote and the other is Ura. Both style[s] have only one top family. Whichever they are, the top family uses [a] special bowl made by [the] Raku family. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: any of a group of similar things
dictionaryExamples: We can go to the seven o'clock performance or the eight - whichever works best.
You can choose whichever of those dates is best for you.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This job [...] is in Central London, and you can choo[se] part-time or full time, whichever you want. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: during the time that, or at the same time as
dictionaryExamples: I read it while you were drying your hair.
While I was in Italy, I went to see Alessandro.
I thought I heard him come in while we were having dinner.
"I'm going to the post office." "While you're there, can you get me some stamps?"
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My mother gave it to me yesterday evening while I was playing [a] comp[u]ter game. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: used to compare two different facts or situations
dictionaryExamples: He earns seventy thousand dollars a year while I earn only forty!
Tom is very confident while Katy is shy and quiet.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In Italy, weddings [are] very traditional! The girls [wear] a long, white dress, while the boys, normally, [wear] dark [clothes]. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: despite the fact that; although
dictionaryExamples: While I accept that he's not perfect in many respects, I do actually like the man.
While I fully understand your point of view, I also have some sympathy for Michael's.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: While it is true that everyone should have a computer at home because it is useful, on the other hand hardly anybody [can] afford [one]. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: a length of time
dictionaryExamples: I only stayed for a short while.
You were there a while, weren't you?
"When did that happen?" "Oh, it was a while ago".
After a while, Roberto came back inside.
I haven't seen him for a while.
I'll be fine in a while.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After a while, a girl invited me to play darts with her and her friends. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: a long time
dictionaryExamples: I hadn’t seen Rebecca in quite a while.
It took quite a while to clean out the garage.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But although I have what you could call "simple" tastes, it takes me quite a while to decide what to buy. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: sometimes but not often
dictionaryExamples: We do go to the beach once in a while.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She did not say very much except for "oh" and "yes, yes" every once in a while. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: when you suddenly want to do something without having a reason
dictionaryExamples: We booked our beach vacation on a whim.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He brought her presents and indulged her every whim. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: a strong, pale brown alcoholic drink that is made from rye, barley, or corn
dictionaryExamples: Tennessee is famous for its bourbon whiskey.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We spent two nights at the inn and had the pleasure to taste all these different kinds of whiskey which have been produced in the area. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: to speak extremely quietly so that other people cannot hear
dictionaryExamples: She leaned over and whispered something in his ear.
What are you two girls whispering about?
"Where is the bathroom?" she whispered.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Around midnight, I woke up, because I heard some people whispering. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: to make a sound by breathing air out through a small hole made with your lips, or through a whistle
dictionaryExamples: On the days when she wore a skirt the men on the building site would whistle at her.
Someone was whistling Beatles tunes outside my window.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I stood up and many of my companions clap[p]ed their hands, although some of them whistled in a very rude way. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: a small, simple instrument that makes a sound when you blow through it
dictionaryExamples: The referee blew his whistle to end the game.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was so nervous and I was thinking about that scream and those whistles, so I decided to go outside to have a look. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: being the color of snow or milk
dictionaryExamples: a white T-shirt
white walls
a black and white dog
He's white-haired now.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Do not wear white clothes! Key English Test; A2; Thai

sense.def: White wine is a pale yellow color.
dictionaryExamples: Would you prefer red or white wine?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Please don't bring anything or if you w[ant to,] bring one bottle of white wine. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Polish

sense.def: Someone who is white has skin that is pale in color.
dictionaryExamples: He had a black mother and a white father.
He's described as a white man in his early thirties.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He had just been beaten by a group of white men. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: having a pale face because you are ill or you are feeling shocked
dictionaryExamples: He was white with shock.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: However, when she opened the door, her face went white. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Chinese

sense.def: relating to white people
dictionaryExamples: the white community
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As most British in those days, his private life lay in a small circle of the white community. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: the color  of snow or milk
dictionaryExamples: In some countries it is traditional for a bride to wear white.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example:  Robbie, [w]e will paint my bedroom in the color white. Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: used to ask about someone's name or which person or group someone is talking about
dictionaryExamples: Who told you?
Who's that?
Who are all those people?
Who's playing in the game this afternoon?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: What did you do at the party? Who was there? Key English Test; A2; Romanian

sense.def: used at the beginning of a relative clause to show which person or group of people you are talking about
dictionaryExamples: That's the man who I saw in the bank.
I think it was your dad who called.
The light woke Shirley, who had been sleeping.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was my mother who gave it to me. Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: used to give more information about someone
dictionaryExamples: My brother, who's 17, has passed his driving test.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The bad guys tr[y] to take over the world and the good guys, who are the heroes [, try] to stop them from doing so. Preliminary English Test; B1; Bengali

sense.def: used to emphasize that you do not think something is important
dictionaryExamples: "Hey, I won again!" "Who cares?"
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: "Who cares?" he answered. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: the person who
dictionaryExamples: Whoever broke the window will have to pay for it.
Could I speak to whoever is in charge of international sales, please?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have to admit that whoever invented cars  [produce]d the [best] invention [in] the world. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: used to say that it is not important which person or group does something
dictionaryExamples: Can whoever leaves last please lock up?
You're likely to get the same answer, whoever you ask.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The main advantage is obvious - you can communicate whenever you want with whoever you want and wherever you are. First Certificate in English; B2; Czech

sense.def: complete, including every part
dictionaryExamples: I spent the whole day cleaning.
There's still a whole month till my birthday.
After my exercise class, my whole body ached.
The whole town was destroyed by the earthquake.
This whole thing  is ridiculous.
Bill does nothing but complain the whole time .
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Did you know that almost the whole class came to my party. Key English Test; A2; Thai

sense.def: generally
dictionaryExamples: We've had a few problems, but on the whole we're very happy.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On the whole I don't like watching television. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: when considered as a group and not in parts
dictionaryExamples: The population as a whole is getting healthier.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To sum up, I can say that the greatest ever invention is the invention of computers, that has affected both indivi[d]uals and society as a whole. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: as a single object and not in pieces
dictionaryExamples: The baby bird swallowed the worm whole.

sense.def: in a completely enthusiastic way
dictionaryExamples: I agreed wholeheartedly with what she said.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: First of all, I have to say that I agree with you wholeheartedly. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: completely
dictionaryExamples: His behavior is wholly unacceptable.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As far as money is concerned, I think that people who only care about earning lots of money do not wholly understand the question. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: used instead of 'who' as the object of a verb or preposition
dictionaryExamples: I met a man with whom I used to work.
There were 500 passengers, of whom 121 drowned.
To whom do you wish to speak?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This is just to let you know with whom I worked. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: used to ask who something belongs to or who someone or something is connected to
dictionaryExamples: Whose bag is this?
Whose car should we take?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Whose fault is [it]? First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: used for adding information about a person or thing just mentioned
dictionaryExamples: We see patients whose families are unable to care for them.
It was an old house, whose basement had been flooded.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My new friend, whose name is Mark, is my co-worker. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: used to ask who something belongs to or who someone or something is connected to
dictionaryExamples: Whose is this bag?
Whose is that book?

sense.def: used to ask about the reason for something
dictionaryExamples: "I'm going home." "Why?"
Why did you choose to live in Phoenix?
Why wait? Let's leave now.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Why couldn't you come? Key English Test; A2; Chinese

blocks.phrase: why don't you?/ why not do sth?

sense.def: used to make a suggestion
dictionaryExamples: Why don't you come with us?
Why not give it a try?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Why don't we play tennis? Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: used to talk about the reason for something
dictionaryExamples: I don't know why she isn't here.
Exactly why he died is a mystery.
There is no reason why we shouldn't succeed.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Also, you didn't say why the photography and painting courses were so popular. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: used to agree with something that someone has suggested
dictionaryExamples: "Let's get some ice cream."  "Sure, why not?"
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She said, I have two tickets for a new film [with] Tom Cruise - would you like to come with me? Well I said why not, so I went with her to see this film. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: extremely bad and morally wrong
dictionaryExamples: a wicked man
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [They went to] great pains to do so, as he was indeed a wicked and cunning man, but he had not counted [on] Caroline's and James' superior intelligence, and the documents were eventually found in an empty jar in the kitchen. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: having a larger distance from one side to the other than is usual or expected
dictionaryExamples: a wide river/road
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm going to stay here two weeks in a big hotel near a wide river. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: having a distance of 5 miles/10 feet, etc. from one side to the other
dictionaryExamples: The swimming pool is 20 feet wide.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: From the two meters wide window I can overlook the city and the lake. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: a lot of different types of thing
dictionaryExamples: The library has a wide range of information.
They sell a wide selection of chocolates.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There is a very wide choice of activities! Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: farther than usual or as far as possible
dictionaryExamples: She ran toward me, her arms open wide.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She came into the living room and saw me standing on the stairs with my eyes opened wide. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: to be completely awake
dictionaryExamples: "Is Oliver awake yet?" "Yes, he's wide  awake and running around his bedroom."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Sometimes, when I have put my children to bed, half an hour later an aircraft flies over and my two-year-old daughter is wide awake again. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: including a lot of different places, people, subjects, etc.
dictionaryExamples: They have both traveled widely.
English is widely spoken around the world.
His work is widely known/accepted.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is widely known that the Japanes[e] and Chines[e] people are often very healthy. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: to be very different
dictionaryExamples: Prices vary widely from store to store.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: People's opinions on the protection of the environment differ widely. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: to become wider, or to make something wider
dictionaryExamples: They are widening the road.
As it approaches the sea, the river begins to widen (out).
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So I suggest widening the [main road]. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to increase or make something increase in number or degree
dictionaryExamples: Why not widen the discussion to include other points of view?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It could help me to widen my knowledge about stamps. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: affecting or including a lot of places, people, etc.
dictionaryExamples: a widespread problem
widespread support
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is because of widespread use of deep-freezing and preservatives. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: a woman whose husband has died and who has not married again
dictionaryExamples: Many of her friends are also widows.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Roland was a rich man and now you are a rich widow. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: the distance across something from one side to the other
dictionaryExamples: It is 5 inches in width.
The needle is seven times smaller than the width of a human hair.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The width of a car hinders driv[ing] on the pavement, for instance. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: to hold a weapon or tool and look as if you are going to use it
dictionaryExamples: They were confronted by a man wielding a knife.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To start with, its special effects are superb, transporting the spectator into a new world of fascinating creatures, who wield mighty weapons to get citizens free from slavery and injustice. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to have a lot of influence or power over other people
dictionaryExamples: People in his position wield a lot of power over our lives.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Fortunately, my parents do not wield authority over me and my siblings like dictators. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: the woman a man is married to
dictionaryExamples: I met Greg's wife for the first time.
She's his third wife.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: How are you, and how are your wife and children? Key English Test; A2; Arabic

sense.def: A wild animal or plant lives or grows in its natural environment and not where people live.
dictionaryExamples: a wild dog
wild flowers
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can see wild animals. Key English Test; A2; Japanese

sense.def: describes land that is not used to grow crops and has few people living in it
dictionaryExamples: a wild mountainous region
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This area is still wild. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: very energetic and not controlled
dictionaryExamples: a wild party
wild dancing
The audience burst into wild applause.
When I told him what I'd done, he went wild.
The children were wild with excitement.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When Jorge went up [on] the stage to get his award, he sang the song and the crowd went wild! First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: If someone, especially a child, runs wild, they behave as they want to and no one controls them.
dictionaryExamples: Their nine-year-old son is left to run wild.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My parents decided to move to a small village when I was just a kid. Shortly after we settled [in], my parents decided that I was running wild and that it was time for me to receive some sort of education. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: If someone's imagination runs wild, they are not able to control their thoughts.
dictionaryExamples: It was getting dark and my imagination was starting to run wild.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Her imagination started to run wild and she [began] to think about the dark corridors, the secret passages and the obscure dungeons that the castle might hide. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: something that you say which is not based on facts or careful thought
dictionaryExamples: I’ll make a wild guess but I don't really know.
You can't go round making wild accusations like that.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And in regard [to the] future, I am afraid, we only can make wild guesses about what is waiting for us out there. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: with a lot of wind, rain, etc.
dictionaryExamples: a wild and stormy night
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They played with the shadows of the night and danced with the sound of a wild wind. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: bigger or better than anything you could imagine or hope for
dictionaryExamples: The house was beyond my wildest dreams.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [It] was beyond my wildest dreams. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: used to say that something is better than anything you could imagine or hope for
dictionaryExamples: Never in my wildest dreams had I thought I would be offered a starring role in a Hollywood movie.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Not even in my wildest dreams could I have imagined that finding a diary was to have such fortunate consequences for me. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: a place that is in a completely natural state without houses, industry, roads, etc.
dictionaryExamples: a beautiful mountain wilderness
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At 7 o'clock we left our tiny hotel to head for the wilderness. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swiss German

sense.def: animals and plants that grow independently of people in their natural environment
dictionaryExamples: a documentary on Peruvian wildlife
wildlife groups/conservation
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The countryside will be the best place because we [will be] able to see the old castles,  mountains and natural areas with forests and wildlife. Preliminary English Test; B1; Amharic

sense.def: in a very energetic way and without control
dictionaryExamples: He was dancing wildly.
They cheered wildly.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When I arrived at the party, I knew immediately that something was wrong ... people were sleeping on the floor, the house furniture was all torn apart, [and] people with beverages were dancing wildly. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: extremely
dictionaryExamples: It's a wildly popular video game.
The product has been wildly successful.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Funding field trips would mean increased resources for our wildly successful guest appearances, as well as the budget needed to foster our skilled debaters. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: used to talk about what someone or something is able or willing to do
dictionaryExamples: I'll give you a ride.
I've asked her but she won't come.
The car won't start.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'll cook for you. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Italian

sense.def: used to talk about what is going to happen in the future, especially things that you are certain about
dictionaryExamples: Ben will be five years old next month.
The train leaves at 8:58, so we'll be in Boston by early afternoon.
I'll see him on Saturday.
Will Susie be there?
It won't be easy to find another secretary.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I will arrive at 8 o'clock. Key English Test; A2; Turkish

sense.def: used to ask someone to do something
dictionaryExamples: Will you give me her address?
Will you give that to Tony when you see him, please?
Will you join us for a drink, Evie?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Will you help me to [paint] my bedroom? Key English Test; A2; Bengali

sense.def: used in conditional sentences that start with 'if' and use the present tense
dictionaryExamples: If he's late again, I'll be very angry.
I won't be surprised if she cancels the trip.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you want [me] to, I'll bring you some of my CDs. Key English Test; A2; Swiss German

sense.def: used to form the future perfect tense
dictionaryExamples: Next month, Gary will have been working here for 10 years.
He'll have reached Denver by tonight.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For a start, if it is quite probabl[e] that scientific [research] will have found how to cure some of the more lethal diseases, e.g. cancer and AIDS, by 2050. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: the mental power used to control and direct your thoughts and actions, or a determination to do something, despite any difficulties or opposition
dictionaryExamples: From an early age she had a very strong will.
After six months in the hospital she began to lose the will to live.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: How would you find the will to look for another job? First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: what someone wants to happen
dictionaryExamples: Against their will, they were forced to hold a meeting.
The state can't just impose its will on local communities.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But if you go [and] learn a language against your will, then it's better not to go at all. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: an official statement of what a person has decided should be done with their money and property after their death
dictionaryExamples: Have you made a will yet?
She left me some money in her will.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This uncle of mine, rich as he was, decided to make a will some years before his death. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: in a willing way
dictionaryExamples: He would willingly risk his life for her.

I would willingly  help you if I
                         weren't going away tomorrow.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Of course, I'll willingly help you, even though I'm going to stay there only for a couple of weeks. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: the state of being willing
dictionaryExamples: I was impressed by her willingness to listen.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Again I appreciated your sense of humor [and] willingness to keep an open home. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: the ability to make yourself do difficult things or to stop yourself from doing enjoyable things that are bad for you
dictionaryExamples: It takes great willpower to lose weight.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the end, I think, it all comes down to willpower and intelligence. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: to get the most points in a competition or game
dictionaryExamples: Which team won the Superbowl last year?
Do you think the Denver Broncos will win?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Portugal is in Euro 2004 and I want Portugal [to] win this tourn[a]ment. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: to get a prize in a game or competition
dictionaryExamples: He won $1,000 for his short story.
This is the third medal she's won this season.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was happy because I won a computer. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: to get the most votes in an election
dictionaryExamples: Who do you think will win the election?

sense.def: to be successful in a war, fight, or argument
dictionaryExamples: They won the war, but with heavy losses.
Everyone likes winning an argument.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After a short battle on the floor I won the fight. First Certificate in English; B2; Norwegian

sense.def: to get approval/respect/support, etc. because of your skill and hard work
dictionaryExamples: Her plans have won the support of many local people.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In my book, they should be prepared to work hard to win their colleagues' respect before they start to earn real money. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: when someone wins a game, competition or election
dictionaryExamples: It was the team's sixth consecutive win this season.
Everyone was predicting a big win at the last election but it didn't happen.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As far as I am concerned, we are a perfect team and we would like to have more spare time as a prize [for] the consecutive easy wins we had. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: a natural, fast movement of air
dictionaryExamples: There isn't enough wind to fly a kite.

There was a light/gentle wind blowing.
There wasn't a breath of  wind.
The wind is beginning to pick up.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There are coconut trees near the sea and sometimes gentle winds blew through [them]. Key English Test; A2; Bengali

sense.def: to take a risk
dictionaryExamples: I decided to throw caution to the wind and book a ticket to India.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They just threw caution to the wind, and did what they wanted. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; [no L1 data]

sense.def: describes a path, road, river, etc. that repeatedly turns in different directions
dictionaryExamples: There's a very long, winding path leading up to the house.

sense.def: a space usually filled with glass in the wall of a building or in a vehicle, to allow light and air in and to allow people inside the building to see out
dictionaryExamples: Is it all right if I open/close the window?
He caught me staring out of the window.
I saw a child's face at the window.
She has some wonderful plants in the window.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Near the window there are some flowers. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: a separate area on a computer screen that shows information and that you can move around
dictionaryExamples: to minimize/maximize a window

sense.def: the window at the front end of a car, bus, etc.
dictionaryExamples: A rock cracked my windshield as I was driving home.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Now you can se[e] the drivers in their cars looking like zombies through the windshield and breathing smog and you reali[z]e how much the "bicycling tour" to [work] in the mornings is worth to you. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: a sport in which you sail across water by standing on a board and holding onto a large sail
dictionaryExamples: The channel is a popular area for windsurfing.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On Thursday if the weather is better we'll go windsurfing. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: with a lot of wind
dictionaryExamples: It was a windy night.
It was wet and windy for most of the week.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was sunny and a little windy, so it wasn't too hot. Preliminary English Test; B1; Catalan

sense.def: an alcoholic drink that is usually made from grapes, or sometimes from other fruit
dictionaryExamples: a wine cellar/glass
red/white/dry/sweet/sparkling wine
Let's have a bottle/glass of wine with dinner.
I love Australian wines, especially the white wines.
Would you like to see the wine list, sir?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like to drink wine or beer. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: one of the body parts that a bird or insect uses to fly
dictionaryExamples: The eagle took off, flapping its wings to gain height.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I enjoyed this place because there w[ere] [a] lot of trees and [a] lot of birds with [colorful] wings. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: one of the two long, flat parts at the sides of an aircraft that allow it to fly
dictionaryExamples: I could see the plane's wing out of the window.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Everything looked good but then, he made a wrong move and crashed into a[nother] plane with the wing. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: a group of people in an organization or political party who have the same beliefs
dictionaryExamples: the conservative/progressive wing of the party

sense.def: to quickly close and then open one eye, in order to be friendly or to show that something is a joke

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: With her blue eyes she looks straight at me and because one eye is slightly closed I alway[s] feel that she winks [at] me. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: to not have any sleep
dictionaryExamples: I was so excited last night - I didn't sleep a wink.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nevertheless, due to the fact that I hadn't slept a wink the previous night, I began to fall asleep. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: someone who wins a game or competition
dictionaryExamples: There'll be a prize for the winner.

And to find out who the lucky winners of our competition are, Samantha is going to draw some names out of the bag.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The winners will get wonderful prizes. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: the coldest season of the year, between fall and spring
dictionaryExamples: Last winter we went skiing.
It's been a very cold/mild winter.
I think you tend to eat more in the winter.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I love my town bec[a]use in winter I can [go] skiing. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Spanish

sense.def: to clean or dry something by moving a cloth across it
