Use a clean sponge to wipe countertops.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you accept my application, I can join any group you've made to help clean the street, [and] wipe the walls or doors of [a] public place. International English Language Testing System; B2; Chinese

sense.def: to remove dirt, water, a mark, etc. from something with a cloth or your hand
dictionaryExamples: He wiped a tear from his eye.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My father gave her a tissue and she wiped her tears away. First Certificate in English; B2; German

blocks.phrasalVerb: wipe sth out or wipe out sth

sense.def: to destroy something completely
dictionaryExamples: The earthquake wiped out many villages.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We are able to cure diseases that hundreds of years ago would wipe out thousands of people, as, for instance, the Black Plague did. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: thin, metal thread used to fasten things or to make fences, cages, etc.
dictionaryExamples: a wire fence

sense.def: a long,  thin piece of metal thread, usually covered in plastic, that carries electricity, telephone signals, etc.
dictionaryExamples: Don't touch those wires whatever you do - they're live.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After carrying stuff like lights, microphones, wires and some other equipment for about three hours, I was e[x]hausted. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: the ability to use your knowledge and experience to make good decisions and judgments
dictionaryExamples: As a coach, he says, he often gleans wisdom from his students.
They had doubts about the wisdom of spending such a sum.
Did we ever stop to question the wisdom of going to war?
Before I went off to college, my father gave me a few words of wisdom.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: However, these two [subjects] are vital for us to obtain the wisdom needed in [later] life. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: what most people believe
dictionaryExamples: These ideas about child care go against the conventional wisdom.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Thus, against conventional wisdom, I think that while a lot of adult problems are caused by money or the lack of it, it is really the ability to deal with money and to see money as a means rather than an end. International English Language Testing System; C1; Malay

sense.def: having or showing the ability to make good judgments, based on a deep understanding and experience of life
dictionaryExamples: I think you made a wise choice.
Judging by the weather, I'd say we made a wise decision not to go to the beach this weekend.
I think it would be wiser to wait and see how much money you  have left before you make any decisions.
I never used to save money, but now that I'm a little older and wiser I can see the sense in it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So, you are coming to my country, that's a wise decision. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: in a wise way
dictionaryExamples: She wisely advised me to wait.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In my opinion, computer learning offers very interesting opportunities, especially to learn new languages, but such a powerful medium as the computer should be used wisely. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Italian

sense.def: the ability to say things that are funny and clever
dictionaryExamples: a woman of great intelligence and wit
He was known for his dry/sharp wit.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: His wit and charm drew many people's attention to the topic and we gained [a] deeper insight in[to] the tourist industry. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Hungarian

sense.def: in stories, a woman who has magical powers that she uses to help or harm people
dictionaryExamples: The story begins with an old witch living in the forest.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A famous actress and her friend, a librarian, get the "elixir of eternal youth" from the mysterious witch (Isabella Rossellini) and then their troubles begin... Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: used to say that people or things are in a place together or are doing something together
dictionaryExamples: I was with Sylvia at the time.
He lives with his grandmother.
I'm going to Mexico with a couple of friends.
Ingrid Bergman starred with Humphrey Bogart in the film 'Casablanca'.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On Sunday afternoon, she goes with her husband and her son to the swim[m]ing pool. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Russian

sense.def: having or including something
dictionaryExamples: a house with a swimming pool
a woman with brown eyes
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I want you to cook rice with fish and olives. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Russian

sense.def: using something
dictionaryExamples: She hit him over the head with a tennis racket.
Fix the two pieces together with glue.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I can print [the] advertisement and tickets with my computer. Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: used to say what fills, covers, etc. something
dictionaryExamples: a bucket filled with water
She filled the pitcher with cream.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was like throwing her into a pool filled with ice. Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi

sense.def: used to describe the way someone does something
dictionaryExamples: He plays with great skill.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: People can do more things and with more energy when [they are] listening to music. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: because of something
dictionaryExamples: I was shaking with fear.
I can't work with all that noise going on.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was Tuesday the 13th and the fact that I was very superstitious made me tremble with fear. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: relating to something or someone
dictionaryExamples: There's something wrong with the car.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [It]'s such a shame when people use [computers] badly, just for damaging and making things worse, because if there's something wrong with them, almost everything is wrong [with] us too. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: relating to a particular thing
dictionaryExamples: I am writing with respect to your letter of June 24.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: With respect to the ages of the members, they are between fifteen and twenty years old. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: used to politely disagree with or give a negative opinion about something
dictionaryExamples: I’ve been thinking about what you said and, with all due respect, I think you’re mistaken.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Finally we would like to point out two [things] that should be improved. The first one is entertainment, which, with all due respect, is very poor. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: using something to help you
dictionaryExamples: She walks with the aid of a cane.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The newest computer can handle data that human brains cannot and therefore all scientific research [is] carried out with the aid of computers. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese

sense.def: with a very high score or with great success
dictionaryExamples: He passed the exam with flying colors.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Thr[o]u[gh] this, he was able to get his college degree and graduated with flying colors. International English Language Testing System; C1; Tagalog

sense.def: without using any type of tool or weapon when doing something that requires a lot of strength
dictionaryExamples: He wrestled the lion to the ground with his bare hands.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You could tell your grandchildren about the good old days when you hunted for mammoths and skinned them with your bare hands, just a few million years back (sigh: "seems like yesterday"). Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: in an excited or anxious way
dictionaryExamples: I waited with bated breath as the results were read out.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nevertheless, a huge number of scientists carrying out very useful research, [and] composers, actors, [and] artists making us watch their creations with bated breath, do not earn [as much] money as a lot of outstanding sportsmen do. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: If you do or say something with a heavy heart, you feel very sad or anxious
dictionaryExamples: It was with a heavy heart that he packed his bags and left his home of many years.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I started to clear the table with a heavy heart, and was still in the process of washing up when the bell rang and, on dashing to open the door - I was the only one that was still up - I was relieved to find that my friends had come to greet me, as is their wont. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: used by someone to express good wishes when they give you something free, for example in a restaurant
dictionaryExamples: Please accept this champagne with the compliments of the manager.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The guest can also choose from a selection of wonderful desserts such as mousse au chocolat with fresh ras[p]berries before finishing his/her meal with a rose lique[u]r - with the compliments of the house (and the bill). Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: to take money out of a bank account
dictionaryExamples: She withdrew $50.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Apart from this, without credit cards I would have to look for a bank to withdraw money, and this is not very easy for a student. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: to remove something, especially because of an official decision
dictionaryExamples: This product has been withdrawn from the store's shelves and will no longer be sold.
He has threatened to withdraw his support.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But the government stepped back, withdrew the proposal and fired three ministers. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French

sense.def: to decide that you will not now be in a race, competition, etc.
dictionaryExamples: Christie was forced to withdraw from the race because of injury.

sense.def: when you take money out of a bank account
dictionaryExamples: The bank became suspicious after several large withdrawals were made from his account in a single week.

sense.def: when something is taken away so that it is no longer available, or when someone stops being involved in an activity
dictionaryExamples: Doctors demanded the withdrawal of the drug (from the market) after several cases involving dangerous side-effects were reported.
Her sudden withdrawal from the championship caused a lot of press speculation about her health.
the withdrawal of financial support

sense.def: quiet and not talking to other people
dictionaryExamples: As winter dragged on, he seemed sadder and more withdrawn.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I should have been friendlier and more interested, rather than quiet and withdrawn. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: before a particular period of time has finished
dictionaryExamples: The ambulance arrived within 10 minutes.
This product should be eaten within three days.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I will return it to you within four days. Preliminary English Test; B1; Tamil

sense.def: less than a particular distance from something
dictionaryExamples: Two-thirds of Californians live within 15 miles of the coast.
The hotel is within easy reach of the airport.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: By the way, [the] receptionist told me that the scenery [a]round the lake is very beautiful and that the Butterfly Farm and the monument shown on your map are within easy reach. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: not outside the limits of something
dictionaryExamples: We came within five points of beating them.
The project was completed well within budget.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Similarly [the] visitor has also shown responsibility to remain within [the] gross limits of the society he is moving [in], so that he cannot cause any hurt or harm to local culture. International English Language Testing System; B2; Panjabi

sense.def: inside an area, group, or system
dictionaryExamples: a dispute within the department
There's a pharmacy in the hospital building.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Sir or Madam, I am writing to you, as requested, in order to ensure that the training - whose purpose is to help the staff improve its communications with the other departments within the company - is effective and not just a waste of time. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: not having, using, or doing something
dictionaryExamples: I came out without my umbrella.
You look nice without makeup.
You shouldn't drive for more than three hours without resting/stopping.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have an exam tomorrow and I cannot study without the folder. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: when someone is not with someone else
dictionaryExamples: I couldn't have done it without you.
You can start the meeting without me.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Majorca is wonderful, but I feel lonely without you. Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: immediately
dictionaryExamples: This problem needs to be dealt with without delay.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Firstly, the programme began on time at midday without delay. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: to not be harmed or broken by something
dictionaryExamples: a bridge designed to withstand earthquakes
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the past older or weaker organisms unable to withstand certain diseases had to die. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: a person who sees an event happening, especially a crime or an accident
dictionaryExamples: The police are appealing for witnesses to the accident to come forward.
According to (eye) witnesses, the robbery was done by two teenage boys.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Furthermore, the witness was assassinated. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: to see something happen, especially an accident or crime
dictionaryExamples: Did anyone witness the attack?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Finally, if you witness an accident you can inform the police quickly, which can save lives. First Certificate in English; B2; Swiss German

sense.def: using words in an intelligent and funny way
dictionaryExamples: a witty comment/remark
He was witty and very charming.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have read it many times and [the] author's witty remarks and elegant style have always been a source of entertainment to me. First Certificate in English; B2; Romanian

sense.def: a wild animal of the dog family
dictionaryExamples: Wolves hunt in groups known as packs.
We could hear wolves howling in the distance.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Before we knew it, Nick leap[t] onto the wolf and they started to fight. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: an adult female person
dictionaryExamples: a 30-year-old woman
She's a really nice woman.
A woman and two men were arrested on the day after the explosion.
Women won the right to vote in the U.S. in 1920.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Your teacher will be a woman. Key English Test; A2; Russian

sense.def: to ask yourself questions or express a wish to know about something
dictionaryExamples: Shouldn't you call home? Your parents will be wondering where you are.
He's starting to wonder whether he did the right thing in accepting this job.
Will this turkey be big enough for eight, I wonder?
"Have you decided where you're going next summer?" "I've been wondering about  going to Florida."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You might wonder why I decided to do so. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: used in phrases, at the beginning of a request, to make it more formal and polite
dictionaryExamples: I wonder - could you help me carry these books?
I wonder whether you could pass me the butter?
I was wondering if you could give me some information about places to visit in the area?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I wonder if there is a way that I would be able to cover the work I have missed? Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi

sense.def: it is not surprising
dictionaryExamples: No wonder the children are excited - this is the first time they've been abroad.
"If brutal killers like these two are at work, it is no wonder that so many people have fled," he said.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: No wonder that people are more tired and are not interested in reading books as much as in the past. First Certificate in English; B2; Czech

sense.def: extremely good
dictionaryExamples: He's a wonderful cook.
"Did you know that Daryl's getting married?" "No, I didn't. How wonderful!"
We had a wonderful time in Italy last summer.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I hope you will have a wonderful time. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Slovak

sense.def: the hard material that trees are made of
dictionaryExamples: He gathered some wood to build a fire.
The box is made of wood and it's very heavy.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is long and it is made of wood. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: made of wood
dictionaryExamples: The house was surrounded by a tall, wooden fence.
Stir the mixture with a wooden spoon.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We [will] bring [some] big wooden tables and chairs. Key English Test; A2; Turkish

sense.def: an area of land with a lot of trees
dictionaryExamples: A lot of the area is woodland.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Our house, which was quite spacious, was near a river and surrounded by beautiful rolling hills and extensive woodland. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: an area of land covered with a thick growth of trees
dictionaryExamples: We went for a walk in the woods after lunch.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The three of us slept together in a small tent, which was located in the heart of the woods. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: thick thread or material that is made from the hair of a sheep
dictionaryExamples: The blankets are made of wool and the sheets are cotton.
Put on your red wool scarf - it'll be nice and warm.
How many balls of wool did you need to knit that sweater?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I got many presents: [a] camera, [a] wool sweater and other things. Key English Test; A2; Arabic

sense.def: a group of letters or sounds that mean something, or a single letter or sound that means something
dictionaryExamples: What's the word for goat in French?
Some words are more difficult to spell than others.
Your essay should be no more than two thousand words long.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When I go to college, I like [to] learn more English words. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Kurdish

sense.def: to not believe/understand/hear/say, etc. anything
dictionaryExamples: I don't believe a word he says.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Peter took my hand and asked me to leave, so I said goodbye to Roger and his girlfriend - who never said a word. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: used to explain what something means in a different way
dictionaryExamples: He said he's too busy - in other words, he isn't interested.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They had had a great time before and had drunk too much alcohol. In other words, they were totally drunk. First Certificate in English; B2; Hungarian

sense.def: to promise someone something
dictionaryExamples: Paolo gave me his word that he wouldn't tell anyone.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I give you my word that it will never happen again. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: to believe what someone says without any proof
dictionaryExamples: Take my word for it - this curry is very hot!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can take my word for it that she is absolutely capable of carrying out this job - fond of children, patient, good-natured and competent. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: to do what you said you would do
dictionaryExamples: He agreed to come and I'm sure he'll keep his word.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It turned out that the company that had been hired to organize it did not keep their word. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Norwegian

sense.def: to talk to someone for a short time
dictionaryExamples: If you have a minute, could I have a word?
I'll have a word with Simon about this.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Tom was not really in the mood to have a word with that annoying man. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Turkish

sense.def: using the exact words that were originally used
dictionaryExamples: She repeated word for word what he had told her.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This is word for word the beginning of the story that Katrina handed to her French teacher. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: used when you repeat what someone said
dictionaryExamples: In the manager's words, the game was "a total disaster."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the immortal words of the bard "... if music be the food of love....... play on!" Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: to be so surprised, angry or moved by something that you do not know what to say
dictionaryExamples: This prize is such an honor and so unexpected - I am lost for words.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was so enraged that I was lost for words for quite a long time. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: not knowing what to say
dictionaryExamples: The question was unexpected and she was temporarily at a loss for words.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If it was James I would be at a loss for words, I didn't know what to tell him. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: by one person telling another telling you
dictionaryExamples: Students learned of the center by word of mouth.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the past news traveled mostly by word of mouth and it took days and sometimes weeks before a person would become aware of an occurrence on the other end of the world. International English Language Testing System; C2; English

sense.def: the place where you go to do your job
dictionaryExamples: Do you have far to travel to work each day?
Thousands of people are seriously injured at work every year.
When does she leave for work?
What time do you start/finish work?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I will finish work at five o'clock. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: something you do as a job to earn money
dictionaryExamples: Has she gotten any work yet?
Many young people are out of work.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [I] like my work. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: the activities that you have to do at school, for your job, etc.
dictionaryExamples: I'll have to take this work home with me and finish it there.
The teacher said she was pleased with my work.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have a lot of work to do this week. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Polish

sense.def: when you use physical or mental effort to do something
dictionaryExamples: Carrying heavy loads around all day is hard work.
I can certainly do a report for you but it will be a lot of work.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The lessons are very good but the teacher is going very quickly. It will be hard work. Preliminary English Test; B1; Czech

sense.def: a painting, book, piece of music, etc.
dictionaryExamples: The museum has many works by Picasso as well as other modern painters.
the complete works of Shakespeare
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We agreed that something had to be done to promote the popularity of local films, some of them being great works of art. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: to do a job, especially the job you do to earn money
dictionaryExamples: She worked as a cleaner at the hospital.
Mike works for a computer company.
My dad works very long hours.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She works [from] Monday to Friday. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Panjabi

sense.def: If a machine or piece of equipment  works, it is not broken.
dictionaryExamples: Our telephone isn't working.
I can't get the radio to work.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I tried to phone her house, but her phone wasn't working, so I decided to go to her house. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: If something works, it is effective or successful.
dictionaryExamples: Her plan to increase sales worked.
The pills will start to work in a few minutes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I changed cars several times to fool the police. It worked very well. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

blocks.phrase: can work sth; know how to work sth

sense.def: to know how to use a machine or piece of equipment
dictionaryExamples: Do you know how to work the video camera?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At that time, I also learned how to work the lighting during the play. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Japanese

sense.def: to try hard to achieve something
dictionaryExamples: You need to work at improving your writing.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In my opinion, this is the part our college has to improve and to work at. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: to spend time repairing or improving something
dictionaryExamples: Tim loves working on old cars.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I believe that it would be best to paint a picture of me in the garage working on my new car. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

blocks.phrasalVerb: work sth out or work out sth

sense.def: to do a calculation to get an answer to a mathematical question
dictionaryExamples: We need to work out the total cost of the project.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I had to work out all my figures two times to make sure that my accounts were accurate. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: to exercise in order to improve the strength or appearance of your body
dictionaryExamples: Heidi works out in the gym two or three times a week.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At the time I use[d] to work out and I [saw] that he was looking [at] me while I was doing my exercises. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: If a problem or a complicated situation works out, it ends in a successful way.
dictionaryExamples: We were worried that the event would be disorganized, but it all worked out in the end.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I hope you follow my instructions and you'll see how everything works out fine. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: someone who works too much and does not have time to do anything else
dictionaryExamples: My husband's a workaholic who never gets home until late at night.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Unless you are a real "workaholic," and there are some of them out there, working like a slave to get more money doesn't pay off. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: a book with questions and spaces to write on, which is used by students for learning a subject
dictionaryExamples: I need to get the workbook for my French class.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I left my workbook in your house.  I really need it because I must finish my homework to show it to the teacher tomor[r]ow! Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: someone who works for a company or organization but does not have a powerful position
dictionaryExamples: factory workers
Many companies still treat their management staff better than their workers.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There is a man with a suitcase and he says: "Hi, I'm a worker in the a[ir]port and I found this suitcase." Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German

sense.def: someone who works quickly/slowly/well, etc.
dictionaryExamples: He's kind of a slow worker, but he is very thorough.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'll recom[men]d you [as] a hard worker and a very nice person. Preliminary English Test; B1; Riff

sense.def: all the people who work for a company or organization
dictionaryExamples: We have a highly skilled workforce.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Before giving them rewards, companies need to train their workforce and identify their potential. International English Language Testing System; C1; Bengali

sense.def: all the people in a country who are able to do a job
dictionaryExamples: 10% of the workforce are unemployed.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There is hardly a nation without representatives in Germany's workforce. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: relating to your job
dictionaryExamples: working hours
Working conditions in the mill have hardly changed over the last twenty years.
She has a difficult working relationship with many of her staff.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But now because of my job, I always [wear] black or dark blue suits [during] working hours. Preliminary English Test; B1; Arabic

sense.def: knowledge about something that is good enough to be useful
dictionaryExamples: She has a working knowledge of German and Russian.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Furthermore, I have a working knowledge of English, Spanish, Catalan and Italian. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: the social group consisting of people who do usually physical work and who often do not get paid much money
dictionaryExamples: He sees the candidate's comments as an attack on the working class.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A member of the working class, for example, was not expected to wear something smart, as he didn't represent the company. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: belonging to or relating to the working class
dictionaryExamples: Working-class families can't afford these prices.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And young people from working-class families in the suburbs of Paris will make a point of having the latest fashion shoes or trousers. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French

sense.def: a period of physical exercise
dictionaryExamples: a light workout
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He teaches me all the workouts [every] day. Preliminary English Test; B1; Tamil

sense.def: the place where you work
dictionaryExamples: We are trying to get rid of bullying in the workplace.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nowadays, our jobs consume more and more of our time so a good atmosphere at the workplace is important. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: when a group of people meet to learn more about something by discussing it and doing practical exercises
dictionaryExamples: a workshop on crime prevention
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All in all, I thoroughly enjoyed this event, but I think there ought to be more computers provided and the numbers of participants to a single workshop should be limited. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: the Earth and all the people, places and things on it
dictionaryExamples: She's traveled all over the world.
News of the disaster shocked the whole world.
We live in a changing world.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like traveling and discovering new place[s] [i]n the world. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Serbian

sense.def: your life and experiences
dictionaryExamples: His whole world fell apart when she left.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like this room because it's "my world" and because it is very big. Key English Test; A2; Italian

sense.def: the people and things that are involved in a particular activity or subject
dictionaryExamples: the entertainment world
the world of politics
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Well, as you know, I'm not very interested in the fashion world, so I rarely spend much time shopping for clothes. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: to have the advantages of two different situations
dictionaryExamples: Living in the country and working in the city you have the best of both worlds.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Only those that can afford to live in the suburban areas can combine the best of both worlds and they tend to be rather affluent. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to be of extremely good quality
dictionaryExamples: Their chocolate cake is just out of this world!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The dessert trays are out of this world. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

blocks.phrase: do sb a world of good

sense.def: to make someone feel much happier or healthier
dictionaryExamples: That swim has done me a world of good.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I feel a year abroad would do her a world of good in letting her care for children, learn to speak English properly, and see life from different aspects. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

blocks.phrase: not be the end of the world

sense.def: If something is not the end of the world, it will not cause very serious problems.
dictionaryExamples: It won't be the end of the world if I don't get this job.

blocks.phrase: be/feel on top of the world

sense.def: to be very happy
dictionaryExamples: I had just won a major tournament and I was feeling on top of the world.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I felt like I was on top of the world and nothing could take that happiness from me. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: existing or happening in all parts of the world
dictionaryExamples: a worldwide success
An increase in average temperature by only a few degrees could cause environmental problems worldwide.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can visit the main monuments of Paris, known worldwide, like Notre-Dame Cathedral or the Eiffel Tower, built in 1903. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: a small creature with a long, thin, soft body and no legs
dictionaryExamples: Blackbirds eat worms, insects, and berries.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Fishing is my hobby and that's why I bought these plastic worms, that are not [very] good - it's better to use live worms! First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: anxious because you are thinking about problems or unpleasant things that might happen
dictionaryExamples: She's really worried about her son.
I'm worried that someone will find out.
She was sitting behind her desk with a worried expression/look on her face.
You had me worried  for a second back there - I thought you wouldn't be able to stop in time.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm worried about your health. Key English Test; A2; Farsi

sense.def: making you feel unhappy and afraid
dictionaryExamples: It's a very worrying situation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But the most worrying thing about this matter is you. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: (comparative of bad) more unpleasant or difficult than something else that is also bad
dictionaryExamples: The test was worse than I expected.
His behavior is even worse than his sister's.
The heat is much worse in the daytime.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It takes me more than one hour to get to work every day. In the evening it is even worse. Skills for Life (Entry 3); B1; Spanish

sense.def: to become more ill, unpleasant, difficult, severe, etc. than before
dictionaryExamples: My cold seems to be getting worse.
If the rain gets any worse, we'll have to stop walking.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I thought, it couldn't get worse. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: used to emphasize how unpleasant, difficult, severe, etc. something is becoming
dictionaryExamples: The economic climate is getting worse and worse.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As we know because of the development of factories and businesses all over the world the air that we are using is getting worse and worse. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: something that is more unpleasant or difficult
dictionaryExamples: "How was the movie?" "I’ve seen worse."
By the third month of the expedition they had endured many hardships, but worse was to follow.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Going down the cliff was hard, but they had seen worse. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: comparative of badly
dictionaryExamples: He did worse than he was expecting to on his driving test.
He was treated much worse than I was.

sense.def: to make a situation more difficult, unpleasant, etc.
dictionaryExamples: To make matters worse, our car broke down!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To make matters worse, the newspaper said they only played for thirty-five minutes. First Certificate in English; B2; Thai

sense.def: to become worse or to make something become worse
dictionaryExamples: His condition suddenly worsened last week.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This changed and worsened severely over the last twenty years. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: to pray to God or a god or to regularly attend religious ceremonies
dictionaryExamples: In the various regions of India, Hindus worship different gods and observe different religious festivals.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The Revolution was of such importance because Greece became a free country again and the people were free to talk, worship their God and have Greek schools. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: to love and admire someone or something very much
dictionaryExamples: She worshipped her mother.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Firstly, many famous people are considered as idols who are worshipped and imitated, which might make them believe they are important, especially when they have a certain media presence. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swiss German

sense.def: the way a person prays or the religious ceremonies people attend
dictionaryExamples: The law would allow workers to take either Saturday or Sunday off as a day of worship.
This is the oldest house of worship in the country.
The meeting house is a center for community worship and study.
Local people have complained about improperly dressed tourists entering places of worship.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There were Holy Masses celebrated by him in several cities and places of worship. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: (superlative of bad) the most unpleasant, difficult or severe
dictionaryExamples: That was the worst meal I've ever eaten.
"It was the worst moment of my life," she admitted.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And you, what is your worst gift? Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: the most unpleasant or difficult thing, person, or situation
dictionaryExamples: That was the worst I've seen him play in several years.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This situation was the worst I have lived [through]. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: used to emphasize the worst thing, situation, etc.
dictionaryExamples: We had no food or light, but worst of all, we had no water.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And worst of all, her mother had been always against that relationship and had given her advice many times. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: to worry that something very bad will happen or that something very bad has happened
dictionaryExamples: When there was no sign of the children, the rescuers feared the worst.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Her parents had been quar[re]lling constantly now for almost half [a] year, and she feared the worst. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: (superlative of badly) the most badly
dictionaryExamples: Small businesses have been worst hit by the recession.
Roads on the western slopes were worst affected by the snow.

sense.def: not important or useful
dictionaryExamples: He made me feel stupid and worthless.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: One important aspect is, of course, that they will feel worthless. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: having no value in money
dictionaryExamples: The painting's a fake - it's completely worthless.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But many people keep completely worthless things for sentimental reasons. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: useful and enjoyable, despite needing a lot of effort
dictionaryExamples: She considers teaching a worthwhile career.
The time and expense involved in keeping up to date with all the changes has been worthwhile.
If you need him on this project, you have to make it financially worthwhile for him.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's a worthwhile trip. You'll have the op[p]ortunity to visit beautiful places and learn lots of history. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: deserving respect, admiration or support
dictionaryExamples: He is unlikely to succeed in getting his bill through Congress, however worthy it is.
Every year she makes a large donation to a worthy cause.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The performers are all neatly dressed and on the whole, they have all made a worthy effort. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: deserving to be given attention, noticed, etc.
dictionaryExamples: Two points in this report are especially worthy of notice.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Try as I might, getting good grades was always met more with a sense of mission accomplished - duly noted - than a feat worthy of congratulations. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: wanting or trying to be
dictionaryExamples: a would-be artist/politician
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Her schoolmates were greatly surprised that a would-be lawyer with a promising career like her had made such a decision. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Chinese

sense.def: an injury, especially one that is made with a knife or bullet
dictionaryExamples: a gunshot wound
a chest/leg wound
a flesh  wound
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Rollo discovered that his best friend was implicated in the penicillin racket: the racketeer would put sand into penicillin without worrying about the great suffering that they caused to people who needed penicillin for their wounds. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: to injure someone, especially with a knife or gun
dictionaryExamples: The police chief was badly wounded in the explosion.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Harry was wounded on his leg. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: used to show surprise, excitement, admiration, etc.
dictionaryExamples: Wow! Did you make that cake? It looks delicious!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Wow, this is very cool! Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German

sense.def: to cover or surround something with paper, cloth or other material
dictionaryExamples: She wrapped the present and tied it with ribbon.
Wrap the chicken in foil and cook it for two hours.

sense.def: to cover someone with material in order to protect them
dictionaryExamples: She wrapped the baby in a blanket.
He wrapped a towel around his shoulders.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After a few seconds I gathered my wits and wrapped the towel around myself again. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

blocks.phrasalVerb: wrap sth up or wrap up sth

sense.def: to fold paper, cloth, etc. around something to cover it
dictionaryExamples: Have you wrapped up Jenny's present?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was wrapped up in paper with a red ribbon. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: to destroy or badly damage something
dictionaryExamples: The explosion wrecked several cars and damaged nearby buildings.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In addition, they [agree] that the solution to the traffic is of utmost importance in a big city, because noise and pollution from car exhaust pipes wreck the nerves of city dwellers. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: a vehicle or ship that has been destroyed or badly damaged
dictionaryExamples: Divers exploring the wreck managed to salvage some coins and jewellery.
The burned-out wrecks of several cars littered the road.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We turned around and saw fumes rising in the air from the wreck of the plane. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: someone who is in a bad physical or mental condition
dictionaryExamples: I was a complete wreck by the end of my exams.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So much of what I really appreciate in this life is connected to music and the events that surround it, so a loss of that would totally dev[a]state me and turn me into a wreck! Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: the parts that remain of a car, ship, or aircraft that has been destroyed
dictionaryExamples: Two survivors were pulled from the wreckage.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I learned from the diary that other passengers and the second pilot hadn't survived and that he had buried them near the wreckage. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: very unhappy or ill
dictionaryExamples: I'd been feeling wretched all day so I went to bed early.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As a result, some people will reali[z]e they were unable to achieve their ends when they were younger and will feel wretched. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: very bad or of poor quality
dictionaryExamples: The refugees were living in wretched conditions.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Because working leads to self-esteem, that is most vital for people, especially when they are in wretched conditions. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Japanese

sense.def: a small line on your face that you get when you grow old
dictionaryExamples: This cream reduces the appearance of wrinkles.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And so time goes by and old age is closing [in]. One morning you notice the wrinkles around your eyes and the gr[a]y hair that doesn't keep any of the old color. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Romanian

sense.def: with a lot of wrinkles
dictionaryExamples: a wrinkled face
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To this day, and for many years to come, this piece of music brings back the dirty wrinkled face of the loneliest person I've ever known. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: the part of the body between the hand and the arm
dictionaryExamples: I sprained my wrist playing squash.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example:  I fell [o]n [some] stair[s] and hurt my wrist. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: to produce letters, words or numbers on a surface or computer
dictionaryExamples: Write your name at the top of the page.
When you fill in the form, please write clearly in black ink.
Can I borrow your laptop tonight - I need to write my essay.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Ev[e]ry le[sson] I read and write loads o[f] sentences. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Bengali

sense.def: to send a letter or email to someone, giving them information or expressing your thoughts or feelings
dictionaryExamples: James hasn't written to me recently.
I wrote my sister a letter.
My mother wrote to give me details about the party.
The travel company has written giving information about the trip.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I can write [my penfriend] a letter twice a week. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: to create a book, story, article, etc. or a piece of music
dictionaryExamples: He's writing a book on Colombia.
She writes for Time magazine.
Walton wrote the Cello Concerto in 1956.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Stephen King wrote this book. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

blocks.phrasalVerb: write sth down or write down sth

sense.def: to write something on a piece of paper so that you do not forget it
dictionaryExamples: Did you write Jo's phone number down?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I wrote the address down and left the restaurant. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

blocks.phrasalVerb: write sb/sth off or write off sb/sth

sense.def: to decide that someone or something is not useful or important
dictionaryExamples: They had written him off before they even met him.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She had written that man off. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

blocks.phrasalVerb: write sth up or write up sth

sense.def: to write something on paper or on a computer in a complete or final form, often using notes you have made
dictionaryExamples: Have you written up that report yet?

sense.def: a person who writes books or articles to be published
dictionaryExamples: a travel/sports/fiction/crime writer
She is a well-known writer of children's books.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The last book I read was a true story written by a young South-American writer. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: the skill or activity of producing words on a surface
dictionaryExamples: Teachers  focus on speaking and writing in the afternoon classes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [I]n my lessons I learn reading, writing and English grammar. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: something that has been written or printed
dictionaryExamples: The writing on the label was too small to read.

sense.def: the way that someone writes
dictionaryExamples: Do you recognize the writing on the envelope?

sense.def: the activity of creating pieces of written work, such as books, stories, poems, etc., or the written work of one person or a group of people
dictionaryExamples: I took a course in creative writing.
She is studying women's writing of the 1930s.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Black humor is a distinguishable feature of his writing. First Certificate in English; B2; Farsi

sense.def: An agreement that is in writing is official and is proof of that agreement.
dictionaryExamples: Please confirm your reservation in writing.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I [am] tell[ing] you in writing that I would like to help you. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: expressed in writing, or involving writing
dictionaryExamples: written instructions
a written exam
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would like you to tell me what subject you're teaching tomorrow and the pages of the homework, so I can do the written test [in the] next class. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: not correct
dictionaryExamples: Three of your answers were wrong.
That clock is wrong - it's 12:30, not 12:15.
I'm sorry, you have the wrong number.
We're going the wrong way.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We [listen to a] tape somet[ime]s, and mark wrong letters. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: to think or say something that is not correct
dictionaryExamples: I was wrong about the time - the store closed at 7, not 8.
You're wrong in thinking that Matt is from the States - he's Canadian.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If I'm not wrong, it is in the living room. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: to produce an answer or result that is not correct, or to say or write something that is not correct
dictionaryExamples: I got most of the answers wrong.
The newspapers got the story completely wrong.

sense.def: If something is wrong, there is a problem.
dictionaryExamples: You've been quiet all evening. Is there anything wrong?
What's wrong?
There's something wrong with my computer.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I didn't kn[o]w him, so I thought that there was something wrong. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: not considered morally acceptable by most people
dictionaryExamples: Children should be taught that violence is wrong.
It is wrong to tell lies.
What's wrong with having a little fun?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To sum up, I think it is wrong to keep animals in zoos. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: not suitable or correct, or not as it should be
dictionaryExamples: She's the wrong person for the job.
It was the wrong time to ask for a raise.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Personally I prefer to think that you gave the job to the wrong person. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Catalan

blocks.phrase: get/start off on the wrong foot

sense.def: to start a relationship or activity badly
dictionaryExamples: He got off on the wrong foot with my parents by arriving late.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: One of the greatest pleasure[s] of reading "The Remains of the Day" would be to see the gradual development of the relationship between Stevens and Miss Kenton. From the beginning, they get off on the wrong foot. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Korean

sense.def: in a way that is not correct
dictionaryExamples: You spelled my name wrong.

sense.def: to develop problems
dictionaryExamples: Something's gone wrong with my computer.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Despite all that went wrong, there was something I really enjoyed. It was visiting the Diamond Cave. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: used when you do not want someone to think that you do not like someone or something
dictionaryExamples: Don't get me wrong, I like her, but she can be very annoying.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Don't get me wrong, I love my aunts, I really do, but not as houseguests. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: not correctly
dictionaryExamples: It has been said - wrongly - that Americans hate government.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Equally, the point about 'staying' is erroneous: we stayed at Riverside Hotel instead of Hotel Astrid, [which] closed last year, [and] Hotel Royal [was] wrongly  [described as having] 'special rates' for students. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: accused or punished unfairly or illegally
dictionaryExamples: She was wrongly convicted of smuggling.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You have also wrongly accused the organi[z]ers of spending too much money on organi[z]ing the event. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek
